issues.title: [Bug] Teams calling non-existent tools
issues.body:
# Description
I have a  'coordinate' Team set-up with multiple Agents. Sometimes, not always, if i ask more complex questions that require 2-3 steps to solve, where the Team should call an agent, wait for the response and based on the response to call another agent, the Team tries to call non-existent tools.

From my experiments I clustered the types of non-existent tools in 3 categories:
1) The Team called a function that the Agents have, but this should be task of the Agent. I don't think the team should have access to the agent's tools.
2) Completely made up function (this happened only once though). The team tried to call "atran_diovricrtnsk" and "atran_ennurlddiovatsay", which seem like a jumbled up version of the atransfer_task_to_memeber
3) The Team tried to call the agent directly. What I mean by that is that instead of transfering to an agent, it tried to call the agent as a tool, and of course it failed saying that it didn't find it.

## Steps to Reproduce
I spent like 20 minutes talking to the team and saw these problems.

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
This is the agents' configuration:
```
agent = Agent(
            name="Agent",
            role=<placeholder>,
            model=base_model,
            tools=[mcp_tools,ReasoningTools(add_instructions=True)],
            storage=pg_storage("agent_sessions"),
            #enable_user_memories=True,
            markdown=True,
            show_tool_calls=True,
            add_history_to_messages=True,
            num_history_responses=3,
            num_history_runs=3,
            read_chat_history=True,
            enable_agentic_memory=True
        )
```

This is the Team configuration:
```
mcp_team = Team(
            name="MCP Tools Team",
            team_id="mcp_tools_team",
            description="Routes questions to the right MCP specialist.",
            members=[
               agent1, agent2
            ],
            mode="coordinate",
            model=base_model,
            tools=[ReasoningTools(add_instructions=True)],
            instructions=<placeholder>,
            storage=pg_storage("mcp_team", mode="team"),
            enable_user_memories=True,
            enable_agentic_memory=True,
            show_members_responses=True,
            markdown=True,
            add_datetime_to_instructions=True,
            show_tool_calls=True,
            enable_agentic_context=True,
            enable_team_history=True,
            num_of_interactions_from_history=3,
            share_member_interactions=True,  # Share interactions
            add_member_tools_to_system_message=False
        )
```

## Expected Behavior
I was expecting the team to only call predefined tools like atransfer_task_to_member.

## Actual Behavior
In some casese, the Team tries to call non-existent functions.

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
Logs
```
DEBUG Tool Calls:                                                                        
    - ID: 'call_TDtGEanDx8T301r4E8YcZodA'                                                          
     Name: 'atransfer_task_to_member'                                                            
     Arguments: 'member_id: agent1, task_description: Find people that acted in the same movies as Samuel L. Jackson., expected_output: List
   of people that acted in the same movies as 'Samuel L. Jackson'.'                                             
    - ID: 'call_4xjv9MvAlmC5Hrrb98PsWqtk'                                                          
     Name: 'atran_diovricrtnsk'                                                               
     Arguments: 'member_id: agent2, task_description: Check if any people that acted in the same movies as Samuel L. Jackson are new actors., expected_output: List of new actors that acted in the same movies as 'Samuel L. Jackson'.'                 
    - ID: 'call_w8TbJCryeAPcJyvMY3GnpBYx'                                                          
     Name: 'atran_ennurlddiovatsay'                                                             
     Arguments: 'member_id: agent3, task_description: Determine if any people that acted in the same movies as Samuel L. Jackson are new actors., expected_output:  List of new actors that acted in the same movies as 'Samuel L. Jackson'.'                          
DEBUG **************************************************************** METRICS *****************************************************************        
DEBUG * Tokens:           input=2857, output=229, total=3086                                             
DEBUG * Prompt tokens details:    {'audio_tokens': 0, 'cached_tokens': 0}                                           
DEBUG * Completion tokens details:  {'accepted_prediction_tokens': 0, 'audio_tokens': 0, 'reasoning_tokens': 0, 'rejected_prediction_tokens': 0}        
DEBUG * Time:            4.7664s                                                           
DEBUG * Tokens per second:      48.0450 tokens/s                                                      
DEBUG * Time to first token:     4.5367s                                                           
DEBUG **************************************************************** METRICS *****************************************************************        
DEBUG Getting function atransfer_task_to_member                                                         
DEBUG Getting function atran_diovricrtnsk                                                            
ERROR   Function atran_diovricrtnsk not found                                                          
DEBUG Getting function atran_ennurlddiovatsay                                                          
ERROR   Function atran_ennurlddiovatsay not found                                                        
DEBUG Running: atransfer_task_to_member(member_id=agent1, task_description=..., expected_output=...)
```

## Environment
- Agno Version: (e.g. v1.4.2)
issues.author: anionescubd

comments.author: zizake
comments.body: I encountered similar issue. Adding the 'add_member_tools_to_system_message=False' helped but sometimes there are cases where the coordinator tries to call a function or tool id that doesn't exist.

comments.author: MahorShekhar
comments.body:
I've also faced similar issues in the past. however I was told `v1.4.2` will fix this issue. But seems issue is still there even in latest version.

CC @dirkbrnd

comments.author: pritipsingh
comments.body:
Hey @anionescubd,
Would you mind upgrading to the latest version of Agno and setting stricter instructions when you get a chance?

Also, to help us investigate further, could you please share the team's config so we can debug it together? Thanks a lot!

comments.author: anionescubd
comments.body:
I am already on the latest version (1.4.2).
The issue occurs when I assign the agent a task that requires a step-by-step approach and 3-4 tools calls, where the output of one tool needs to be used as the input for another tool ‚Äî and these tools are managed by different agents.

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body:
Hi @anionescubd 
Looking into it!

issues.title: [Bug] v1.4.6 affects the ability to perform data analysis using tools
issues.body:
### Description

I used the same code to compare the output results of versions v1.4.5 and v1.4.6. 
v1.4.5 provided satisfactory answers, but v1.4.6 did not.

### Steps to Reproduce

import json, os
from pathlib import Path
from textwrap import dedent
from threading import Lock
from typing import Any, Dict, Generator, List, Optional, Mapping

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.azure import AzureOpenAI
from agno.tools.python import PythonTools
from agno.tools.reasoning import ReasoningTools
from fastapi import APIRouter, File, Form, HTTPException, Request, UploadFile
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse, StreamingResponse
from pydantic import BaseModel


class EmployeeMemory(BaseModel):
    conversation_history: List[Dict[str, str]] = []
    temp_path: Optional[str] = None
    cache_dir: Optional[str] = None


class AnalysisRequest(BaseModel):
    employee_id: str
    query: str


class StreamChunk(BaseModel):
    stage: str
    message: Optional[str] = None
    is_end: bool


router = APIRouter()
employee_locks = {}
EMPLOYEE_MEMORIES_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))), "temp_files")


def get_employee_dir(employee_id: str) -> str:
    """Ëé∑ÂèñÂëòÂ∑•Êï∞ÊçÆÁõÆÂΩïË∑ØÂæÑ"""
    os.makedirs(EMPLOYEE_MEMORIES_PATH, exist_ok=True)
    employee_dir = os.path.join(EMPLOYEE_MEMORIES_PATH, employee_id)
    os.makedirs(employee_dir, exist_ok=True)
    return employee_dir


def create_employee_lock(employee_id: str) -> Lock:
    """ÂàõÂª∫ÂëòÂ∑•ÈîÅ"""
    if employee_id not in employee_locks:
        employee_locks[employee_id] = Lock()
    return employee_locks[employee_id]


def load_employee_memory(employee_id: str) -> EmployeeMemory:
    """Âä†ËΩΩÂëòÂ∑•ËÆ∞ÂøÜÊï∞ÊçÆ"""
    with create_employee_lock(employee_id):
        employee_dir = get_employee_dir(employee_id)
        memory_file = os.path.join(employee_dir, "memory.json")
        if os.path.exists(memory_file):
            with open(memory_file, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
                return EmployeeMemory.model_validate(json.load(file))
        return EmployeeMemory()


def save_employee_memory(employee_id: str, memory: EmployeeMemory):
    """‰øùÂ≠òÂëòÂ∑•ËÆ∞ÂøÜÊï∞ÊçÆ"""
    with create_employee_lock(employee_id):
        employee_dir = get_employee_dir(employee_id)
        memory_file = os.path.join(employee_dir, "memory.json")
        with open(memory_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as file:
            json.dump(memory.model_dump(), file, ensure_ascii=False, indent=2)


def create_analyze_agent(python_dir: str) -> Agent:
    """ÂàõÂª∫Êï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûê‰ª£ÁêÜ"""
    llm_azure = AzureOpenAI(
        temperature=0,
        api_key="„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ",
        api_version="2024-10-21",
        azure_endpoint="„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ",
        azure_deployment="gpt-41"
    )

    return Agent(
        model=llm_azure,
        tools=[
            ReasoningTools(add_instructions=True),
            PythonTools(Path(python_dir)),
        ],
        instructions=dedent(
            """\
            ## Ë¶ÅÊ±ÇÔºö
            - ÈáçË¶ÅÔºö‰ΩøÁî®‰∏≠ÊñáËøõË°åÊÄùËÄÉ„ÄÇ
            - ÂßãÁªàÂÖà‰ΩøÁî®ÊÄùËÄÉÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Ê¢≥ÁêÜÂÆåÊàê‰ªªÂä°ÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑÊ≠•È™§„ÄÇ
            - Âú®ÂõûÂ∫îÁî®Êà∑‰πãÂâçÔºåÊî∂Âà∞PythonÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÁªôÂá∫ÁöÑÁªìÊûúÂêéÔºå‰ΩøÁî®ÊÄùËÄÉÂ∑•ÂÖ∑‰Ωú‰∏∫ËçâÁ®øÊú¨ÔºåÂèçÂ§çÈ™åËØÅÁªìÊûúÁöÑÊ≠£Á°ÆÊÄß„ÄÇ
            - ÁêÜËß£ÂΩìÂâçÈóÆÈ¢ò‰∏é‰πãÂâçÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ªÔºåËØÜÂà´ÂΩìÂâçÈóÆÈ¢òÊòØÂê¶Âü∫‰∫é‰πãÂâçÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÁªìÊûúÔºåÊòØÂê¶ÈúÄË¶ÅÂºïÁî®‰πãÂâçÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÊàñÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇ
            - ÊúÄÁªà‰∏∫Áî®Êà∑ËæìÂá∫ÁªèËøá‰∏•Ë∞®ÊÄùËÄÉÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûêÁªìÊûúÔºå‰∏çË¶ÅËæìÂá∫Á±ª‰ºº‚ÄúËØ∑Êü•ÁúãËæìÂá∫ÁªìÊûú‰ª•Ëé∑ÂèñËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ø°ÊÅØ‚ÄùËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÁªìÊûúÔºå‰ºòÂÖàËÄÉËôëËæìÂá∫Ë°®Ê†º„ÄÇ
            - Â¶ÇÊûú‰πãÂâçÂ∑≤ÁªèÈóÆËøáÂπ∂ÂõûÁ≠îËøáËøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂ∞±ÂÆåÂÖ®ÊåâÁÖß‰πãÂâçÁªôÂá∫ÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°àÂõûÂ§ç„ÄÇ
            
            ## ‰ΩøÁî®PythonÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Ôºö
            - ‰ΩøÁî®PythonÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÂàÜÊûêÊï∞ÊçÆÔºå‰∏çË¶ÅÂÅáËÆæÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®ÂíåÂ≠óÊÆµÔºåÂ∫îÂÖàÊµèËßàÁºìÂ≠òÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®ÂêçÁß∞ÂíåÂ≠óÊÆµÂêçÁß∞ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊ†πÊçÆÁî®Êà∑ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑËØ≠‰πâËøõË°åÂàÜÊûêÂà§Êñ≠Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÊòéÁ°ÆÂåπÈÖçÊàñÂØÜÂàáÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµ„ÄÇ

            ## ‰ΩøÁî®ÊÄùËÄÉÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Ôºö
            - Áî±‰∫éÊØè‰∏™ÊÄùËÄÉÊ≠•È™§ÊâßË°åÁéØÂ¢ÉÈÉΩ‰ºöÈáçÁΩÆÔºå‰ΩøÁî®‰ª•‰∏ãÊñπÊ≥ïÈÅøÂÖçÈáçÂ§çËØªÂèñÊñá‰ª∂Âπ∂ËØÜÂà´ÂºÇÂ∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúË°®Ôºö
                1.ËÆæÁΩÆÁéØÂ¢ÉÔºö
                    - ‰ΩøÁî®‰∏≠Êñá‰ª£Á†ÅÊ≥®Èáä„ÄÇ
                    - ËÆæÁΩÆÊòæÁ§∫ÊâÄÊúâÂàóÂèäÈÄÇÂΩìÁöÑË°åÊï∞„ÄÇ
                    - ÂØºÂÖ•pandas„ÄÅosÁ≠âÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÂ∫ì„ÄÇ
                2.Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°ËØªÂèñÊñá‰ª∂Êó∂ÔºåËØÜÂà´ÂºÇÂ∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúË°®Âπ∂‰ΩøÁî®ÁºìÂ≠òÁ≠ñÁï•Ôºö
                    - ÂºÇÂ∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúË°®ÁöÑÂà§Êñ≠Ê†áÂáÜÔºö
                        a. Ë°åÊï∞Â∞ë‰∫é5Ë°åÊàñÂàóÊï∞Â∞ë‰∫é2ÂàóÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®
                        b. Êï∞ÊçÆÂ°´ÂÖÖÁéá‰Ωé‰∫é30%ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®
                        c. ÂàóÂêçÂÖ®ÈÉ®ÊàñÂ§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÊòØÊï∞Â≠óÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®
                        d. ÂåÖÂê´Â§ßÈáèÂêàÂπ∂ÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®
                        e. ÂâçÂá†Ë°åÈÉΩÊòØÁ©∫ÂÄºÊàñNaNÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®
                    - ËØªÂèñExcelÊñá‰ª∂ÂêéÔºåËØÜÂà´Âá∫ÂºÇÂ∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúË°®Âπ∂Ë∑≥ËøáÔºåÁ´ãÂç≥Â∞ÜÊúâÊïàÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®‰øùÂ≠ò‰∏∫ÂçïÁã¨ÁöÑpickleÊñá‰ª∂Âà∞‰∏¥Êó∂ÁõÆÂΩï„ÄÇ
                    - Á§∫‰æã‰ª£Á†ÅÔºö
                        ```python
                        import pandas as pd
                        import os
                        from pathlib import Path
                        
                        # ËØªÂèñExcelÊñá‰ª∂
                        excel_path = r"Êñá‰ª∂Ë∑ØÂæÑ"
                        cache_dir = r"ÁºìÂ≠òÁõÆÂΩï"
                        os.makedirs(cache_dir, exist_ok=True)
                        
                        # ËØªÂèñÊâÄÊúâÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®Âπ∂ÁºìÂ≠ò
                        excel_file = pd.ExcelFile(excel_path)
                        sheet_names = excel_file.sheet_names
                        
                        # ÊâìÂç∞Â∑•‰ΩúË°®‰ø°ÊÅØ
                        print(f"Êñá‰ª∂ÂåÖÂê´‰ª•‰∏ãÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®: {sheet_names}")
                        
                        # ‰øùÂ≠òÊØè‰∏™Â∑•‰ΩúË°®Âà∞ÁºìÂ≠ò
                        for sheet in sheet_names:
                            df = pd.read_excel(excel_file, sheet_name=sheet)
                            # Âà†Èô§ Unnamed Âàó
                            unnamed_cols = [col for col in df.columns if 'Unnamed:' in str(col)]
                            if unnamed_cols:
                                df = df.drop(columns=unnamed_cols)
                            # ‰øùÂ≠òÂà∞ÁºìÂ≠ò
                            cache_path = os.path.join(cache_dir, f"{sheet}.pkl")
                            df.to_pickle(cache_path)
                            print(f"Â∑≤ÁºìÂ≠òÂ∑•‰ΩúË°® '{sheet}' Âà∞ {cache_path}")
                        ```
                3.Âú®ÂêéÁª≠Ê≠•È™§‰∏≠Ôºå‰ªéÁºìÂ≠òËØªÂèñÊï∞ÊçÆËÄåÈùûÂéüÂßãÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåÂè™ÂàÜÊûêÊúâÊïàÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®Ôºö
                    - Á§∫‰æã‰ª£Á†ÅÔºö
                        ```python
                        import pandas as pd
                        import os

                        # ‰ªéÁºìÂ≠òËØªÂèñÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®
                        cache_dir = r"ÁºìÂ≠òÁõÆÂΩï"

                        # Âú®ÁºìÂ≠òÁõÆÂΩï‰∏≠Êü•Êâæ .pkl Êñá‰ª∂
                        pkl_files = [f for f in os.listdir(cache_dir) if f.endswith(".pkl")]

                        if not pkl_files:
                            print(f"Âú®ÁõÆÂΩï '{cache_dir}' ‰∏≠Êú™ÊâæÂà∞ .pkl ÁºìÂ≠òÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ")

                        sheet_name_with_ext = "Âú® pkl_files ‰∏≠ÈÄâÊã©Ë¶ÅÂàÜÊûêÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊàñÂ§ö‰∏™Â∑•‰ΩúË°®"
                        cache_path = os.path.join(cache_dir, f"{sheet_name_with_ext}")
                        
                        if os.path.exists(cache_path):
                            df = pd.read_pickle(cache_path)
                            print(f"‰ªéÁºìÂ≠òÂä†ËΩΩÂ∑•‰ΩúË°® '{sheet_name_with_ext}' ")
                        else:
                            print(f"ÁºìÂ≠òÊñá‰ª∂ '{cache_path}' ‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®ÔºåËØ∑ÂÖàÁºìÂ≠òÊï∞ÊçÆ")
                        ```
                4.‰∏çË¶ÅÂøòËÆ∞ÂØºÂÖ•pandas„ÄÅosÁ≠âÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÂ∫ì„ÄÇ
                5.ÂØπ‰∫éÊØè‰∏™Áî®Êà∑ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂè™ÂØπÊúâÊïàÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®ËøõË°åÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇ
                6.Êü•ÁúãÂπ∂Á°ÆËÆ§Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®Ôºö‰∏çË¶ÅÂÅáËÆæÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®ÔºåÂ∫îÂÖàÊµèËßàÁºìÂ≠òÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®ÂêçÁß∞ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂÜçÊù•Á°ÆÂÆöË¶Å‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúË°®„ÄÇ
                7.Êü•ÁúãÂπ∂Á°ÆËÆ§Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµÔºö‰∏çË¶ÅÂÅáËÆæÂ≠óÊÆµÔºåÂ∫îÂÖàÊµèËßàÁºìÂ≠òÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµÂêçÁß∞ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊ†πÊçÆÁî®Êà∑ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑËØ≠‰πâËøõË°åÂàÜÊûêÂà§Êñ≠Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÊòéÁ°ÆÂåπÈÖçÊàñÂØÜÂàáÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµ„ÄÇ
                8.Á°ÆËÆ§ÊòØÂê¶ÈúÄË¶ÅÂàÜÁªÑËÆ°ÁÆó‰∏éÊéíÂ∫èÔºö‰∏çË¶ÅÂÅáËÆæÂ≠óÊÆµÔºåÂ∫îÂÖàÊµèËßàÁºìÂ≠òÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµÂêçÁß∞ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊ†πÊçÆÁî®Êà∑ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑËØ≠‰πâËøõË°åÂàÜÊûêÂà§Êñ≠Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÊòéÁ°ÆÂåπÈÖçÊàñÂØÜÂàáÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµËøõË°åÂàÜÁªÑÂéªÈáçËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ
                9.ËøõË°åÂâ©‰ΩôÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûêÊ≠•È™§Ôºö
                    - Â≠óÊÆµÂÖ≥ËÅî‰∏éÂêàÂπ∂ÔºöÂ¶ÇÈúÄË¶ÅÂêàÂπ∂Â§ö‰∏™Â∑•‰ΩúË°®Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÁºìÂ≠òÊï∞ÊçÆËøõË°åÊìç‰Ωú„ÄÇ
                    - Êï∞ÊçÆÂéªÈáç‰∏é‰∏ÄËá¥ÊÄßÊ£ÄÊü•ÔºöÊ£ÄÊü•ÊòØÂê¶Â≠òÂú®ÈáçÂ§çÊï∞ÊçÆÊàñÂºÇÂ∏∏ÂÄº„ÄÇ
                    - È™åËØÅÁªìÊûúÔºöÁ°Æ‰øù‰ª£Á†ÅÊâßË°åÊó†ËØØÔºåÂπ∂ÂØπÁªìÊûúËøõË°åÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑËß£Èáä„ÄÇ\
            """
            ),
        add_history_to_messages=True,
        num_history_responses=10,
        markdown=True,
        show_tool_calls=True,
    )


@router.post("/upload_file_stream")
async def upload_file_stream(
    employee_id: str = Form(...),
    file_ext: str = Form(...),
    file: UploadFile = File(...),
):
    """Êñá‰ª∂ÊµÅ‰∏ä‰º†"""
    if not employee_id:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="ÂëòÂ∑•ID‰∏çËÉΩ‰∏∫Á©∫")
    
    if not file_ext:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="Êñá‰ª∂Á±ªÂûã‰∏çËÉΩ‰∏∫Á©∫")
    
    if not file or not file.filename:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="Êñá‰ª∂‰∏çËÉΩ‰∏∫Á©∫")
    
    try:
        file_size = 0
        chunk = await file.read(1024)
        if not chunk:
            raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="‰∏ä‰º†ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ÂÜÖÂÆπ‰∏∫Á©∫")
        # ÈáçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂ÊåáÈíàÔºå‰ª•‰æøÂêéÁª≠ËØªÂèñÂÆåÊï¥ÂÜÖÂÆπ
        await file.seek(0)
    except Exception as e:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail=f"Êñá‰ª∂È™åËØÅÂ§±Ë¥•: {str(e)}")
    
    filename = f"upload_file.{file_ext}"

    try:
        content = await file.read()
        file_size = len(content)
        max_size = 10 * 1024 * 1024

        if file_size > max_size:
            raise HTTPException(
                status_code=400,
                detail=f"Êñá‰ª∂Â§ßÂ∞èË∂ÖËøáÈôêÂà∂(10MB)ÔºåÂΩìÂâçÂ§ßÂ∞èÔºö{file_size/1024/1024:.2f}MB",
            )

        file_extension = Path(filename).suffix.lower()
        if file_extension not in [".xlsx", ".xls", ".csv"]:
            raise HTTPException(
                status_code=400,
                detail=f"‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂Á±ªÂûãÔºö{file_extension}Ôºå‰ªÖÊîØÊåÅ .xlsx, .xls, .csv",
            )

        memory = load_employee_memory(employee_id)
        employee_dir = get_employee_dir(employee_id)

        if memory.temp_path and os.path.exists(memory.temp_path):
            try:
                os.unlink(memory.temp_path)
            except:
                pass

        file_path = os.path.join(employee_dir, filename)

        with open(file_path, 'wb') as file:
            file.write(content)

        memory.temp_path = file_path
        memory.cache_dir = employee_dir
        memory.conversation_history = []

        save_employee_memory(employee_id, memory)

        return JSONResponse(
            content={"choices": [{"message": {"content": "Êñá‰ª∂‰∏ä‰º†ÊàêÂäü"}}]}
        )

    except Exception as exception:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=500, detail=f"Êñá‰ª∂‰∏ä‰º†Â§±Ë¥•: {str(exception)}")


@router.post("/analyze_stream")
async def analyze_stream(request: AnalysisRequest):
    """Êï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûê"""
    def generate_stream() -> Generator[str, None, None]:
        if not request.employee_id:
            error_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="error", message="ÂëòÂ∑•ID‰∏çËÉΩ‰∏∫Á©∫", is_end=True)
            error_json = json.dumps(error_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
            yield f"data: {error_json}\n\n"
            return

        if not request.query:
            error_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="error", message="ÈóÆÈ¢ò‰∏çËÉΩ‰∏∫Á©∫", is_end=True)
            error_json = json.dumps(error_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
            yield f"data: {error_json}\n\n"
            return

        memory = load_employee_memory(request.employee_id)
        if not memory.temp_path:
            error_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="error", message="ËØ∑ÂÖà‰∏ä‰º†Êñá‰ª∂", is_end=True)
            error_json = json.dumps(error_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
            yield f"data: {error_json}\n\n"
            return
        
        context = f"Êñá‰ª∂Ë∑ØÂæÑÔºö{memory.temp_path}ÔºåÁºìÂ≠òÁõÆÂΩïÔºö{memory.cache_dir}"
        if memory.conversation_history and len(memory.conversation_history) >= 2:
            last_query = memory.conversation_history[-2]["content"]
            last_answer = memory.conversation_history[-1]["content"]
            context += f"\n\n‰∏ä‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÊòØÔºö{last_query}\n\n‰∏ä‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÁöÑÂõûÁ≠îÊòØÔºö{last_answer}"

        full_query = f"{context}\n\nÈóÆÈ¢òÔºö{request.query}"

        analyze_agent = create_analyze_agent(memory.cache_dir)
        tool_index = 0
        response_content = ""

        try:
            response_stream = analyze_agent.run(full_query, stream=True, stream_intermediate_steps=True)
            step = 1
            for chunk in response_stream:
                if chunk.event == "ReasoningStep":
                    reasoning_step = f"\n\n## Á¨¨{step}Ê≠•-{chunk.content.title} ##\n\n{chunk.content.reasoning}\n\n"
                    reasoning_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="thinking", message=reasoning_step, is_end=False)
                    reasoning_json = json.dumps(reasoning_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
                    yield f"data: {reasoning_json}\n\n"
                    step += 1

                elif chunk.event == "ToolCallStarted":
                    code = chunk.tools[tool_index]["tool_args"].get("code")
                    if code:
                        reasoning_step = f"{code}\n\n"
                        reasoning_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="thinking", message=reasoning_step, is_end=False)
                        reasoning_json = json.dumps(reasoning_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
                        yield f"data: {reasoning_json}\n\n"
                    tool_index += 1

                elif chunk.event == "RunResponse" and chunk.content:
                    if not response_content:
                        end_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="thinking", message="", is_end=True)
                        end_json = json.dumps(end_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
                        yield f"data: {end_json}\n\n"
                    response_content += chunk.content
                    content_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="content", message=chunk.content, is_end=False)
                    content_json = json.dumps(content_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
                    yield f"data: {content_json}\n\n"

            memory.conversation_history.append({"role": "user", "content": request.query})
            memory.conversation_history.append({"role": "assistant", "content": response_content})
            save_employee_memory(request.employee_id, memory)

            end_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="content", message="", is_end=True)
            end_json = json.dumps(end_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
            yield f"data: {end_json}\n\n"

        except Exception as exception:
            error_chunk = StreamChunk(stage="error", message=str(exception), is_end=True)
            error_json = json.dumps(error_chunk.model_dump(), ensure_ascii=False)
            yield f"data: {error_json}\n\n"

    return StreamingResponse(
        generate_stream(),
        media_type="text/event-stream"
    )


@router.post("/clear_conversation")
async def clear_conversation(query_body: Mapping[str, Any]):
    """Ê∏ÖÈô§‰ºöËØù"""
    if 'employee_id' not in query_body:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="ÂëòÂ∑•ID‰∏çËÉΩ‰∏∫Á©∫")
    
    employee_id = query_body["employee_id"]

    with create_employee_lock(employee_id):
        temp_dir = get_employee_dir(employee_id)
        if os.path.exists(temp_dir):
            try:
                import shutil
                shutil.rmtree(temp_dir, ignore_errors=True)

                return JSONResponse(
                    content={"choices": [{"message": {"content": "Ê∏ÖÈô§‰ºöËØùÊàêÂäü"}}]}
                )

            except Exception as exception:
                raise HTTPException(status_code=500, detail=f"Ê∏ÖÈô§‰ºöËØùÂ§±Ë¥•: {str(exception)}")

issues.title: [Bug] OpenRouter model can't call tools
issues.body:
# Description
OpenRouter model can't call mcp tools

## Steps to Reproduce
```

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.tools.mcp import MCPTools
from mcp import StdioServerParameters
from agno.models.openrouter import OpenRouter

async def run_agent(message: str) -> None:
    """Run the filesystem agent with the given message."""

    file_path = str(Path(__file__).parent.parent.parent.parent)

    # MCP server to access the filesystem (via `npx`)
    async with MCPTools(f"npx -y @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem {file_path}") as mcp_tools:
        agent = Agent(
            model=OpenRouter(id="deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324"),
            tools=[mcp_tools],
            instructions=dedent("""\
                You are a filesystem assistant. Help users explore files and directories.

                - Navigate the filesystem to answer questions
                - Use the list_allowed_directories tool to find directories that you can access
                - Provide clear context about files you examine
                - Use headings to organize your responses
                - Be concise and focus on relevant information\
            """),
            markdown=True,
            show_tool_calls=True,
        )

        # Run the agent
        await agent.aprint_response(message, stream=True)


# Example usage
if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Basic example - exploring project license
    asyncio.run(run_agent("What is the license for this project?"))
```


## Environment
- OS: (Ubuntu)
- Agno Version: (e.g. v1.4.5)

issues.title: [Bug] PDFs from the same author using PDFKnowledgeBase
issues.body:
# Description
Apologies if this is not a bug, but I couldn't find any information in the docs related to this in the docs.

I am trying to load approx. 50 files in my knowledge base for my Agent:

```Python
KNOWLEDGE_BASE = PDFKnowledgeBase(
    path="data/partizanai_pdf_documents",
    vector_db=PgVector(
        table_name="partizanai_pdf_documents",
        db_url=DB_URL,
        # Default used is this one. This is from the code, because in docs it
        # says "text-embedding-ada-002":
        # embedder=OpenAIEmbedder(id="text-embedding-3-small"),
    ),
)

```

There are books which have the same author. Example of exact PDF file names:

`Auksute_Ramanauskaite-Skokauskiene.-.Laisves_deklaracija_ir_jos_signatarai.2009.LT`

and

`Auksute_Ramanauskaite-Skokauskiene.-.Partizanu_vadas_generolas_Adolfas_Ramanauskas-Vanagas.2007.LT`

It adds the vector embeddings to my PostgreSQL database, but when attempting to add vectors to the second book, getting an error that `id Auksute_Ramanauskaite-Skokauskiene_2_1` (I think?) already exists and this violates non-null constraint:

```bash
[2025-05-05 09:18:16,425: ERROR/ForkPoolWorker-8] Task partizanai.load_knowledge_base[33fe861b-cec2-4f71-8c92-735db00a1f30] raised unexpected: IntegrityError('(psycopg.errors.UniqueViolation) duplicate key value violates unique constraint "partizanai_pdf_documents_pkey"\nDETAIL:  Key (id)=(Auksute_Ramanauskaite-Skokauskiene_2_1) already exists.')
```

Example vector db entries from the 1st book that was added successfully:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c648279d-1627-4ad4-bef1-dfd9d7586f1c)

Maybe it's somehow possible to workaround this? You could also point me to the code where I could override where this `id` field is set. 

Ideally I would like to maintain proper references to the book's author when chatting with the Agent if possible.

issues.title: Teams and tool descriptions in team system prompt
issues.body:
I'm curious about what the purpose is of including team member tool descriptions into the system prompt for a team member. This makes the total team prompt huge if team members are specialized and have several tools. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e70af33c-1df5-4f05-acca-0b01c3ffdd26)

I have tried removing this block and the results seem better for me than with this block in place. 

I think the idea with team members should be to minimize model token usage by delegating specialized tasks to team members who then only include their own tools into the subsequent message. 

Also, tools are included already into the model request so why should we also be including them into the system prompt? 

What do you guys think?
issues.author: mkschreder

issues.title: [Bug]: Concurrent calls to Agent using `arun` are mixing RunResponses
issues.body:
# Description
Concurrent calls to Agent are getting mixed together. I found this while working on https://github.com/mozilla-ai/any-agent/pull/225. I fixed a bug in our code that was causing traces/results from concurrent calls to be jumbled together. However, when I fixed the bug in any-agent, I then observed that my tests were now passing on all frameworks (google_adk/openai_agents/smolagents/llama_index/langchain) but continued to fail on Agno, which leads me to believe that there may be a bug in the agno implementation of `arun`. 


## Steps to Reproduce
This is just a snippet but basically, if you have a function like
```
  async def run_async(self, prompt: str, **kwargs: Any) -> "AgentTrace":
      if not self._agent:
          error_message = "Agent not loaded. Call load_agent() first."
          raise ValueError(error_message)
      result: RunResponse = await self._agent.arun(prompt, **kwargs)
      return AgentTrace(
          final_output=result.content,
      )
```
and then you do 
```
result1, result2 = await asyncio.gather(
        agent.run_async("What is the capital of France?"),
        agent.run_async("What is the capital of Spain?"),
    )
assert "Paris" in result1.final_output
assert "Madrid" in result2.final_output
```

You will observe that both results contain the same answer (either Paris, or Madrid) which leads me to believe that there is some memory sharing happening in agno under the hood that isn't isolating the two runs. I may be wrong so please help fill in my knowledge gap if this is the case üòÖ 



## Agent Configuration (if applicable)

https://github.com/mozilla-ai/any-agent/blob/main/src/any_agent/frameworks/agno.py

## Expected Behavior
I expected each async run to have its unique result

## Actual Behavior
the agent runs both contained the same result

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
Include any relevant screenshots or error logs that demonstrate the issue.

## Environment
agno==1.4.5

## Possible Solutions (optional)
Suggest any ideas you might have to fix or address the issue.

## Additional Context
Add any other context or details about the problem here.
issues.author: njbrake

comments.author: kausmeows
comments.body:
Hi @njbrake thanks a lot for raising this, its indeed an issue from the `arun` implementation. I've fixed this in the PR- https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/pull/3138

Should be released soon after some testing!

comments.author: njbrake
comments.body: @kausmeows great, thanks!

comments.author: monali7-d
comments.body:
Hey @njbrake 
sorry about that, reopened the issue

comments.author: kausmeows
comments.body: Hey @njbrake , sorry about the oversight, its merged now!!

issues.title: Thinking tools can not be called on the client
issues.body:
# Description
Due to special handling of thinking tools, the tool can not be instantiated on the client instead of server. It has to be attached directly to the agent (ie has to be on the server). 

## Steps to Reproduce

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6c3441b8-c5e5-4b04-bcca-9cea23369d1e)

## Alternative solutions

While running the thinking tool on the server would work, we should in general try to make it possible to run tools remotely on the client or on the server just the same. This means that tool description must always include ALL tool parameters and the model should be able to instantiate all tool parameters as json.
issues.author: mkschreder

comments.author: ysolanky
comments.body:
Hello @mkschreder ! Yes, you are right. As the thinking tool alters the state of the Agent itself, it takes the Agent as an argument. This is different from the way tools usually work.

If a function includes "agent" as a param, during the execution of the function, we give it access to the Agent in

issues.title: [Bug] Structured Output + MCP Sequential Thinking = schema errror from OpenAI
issues.body:
# Description
When trying to use a Pydantic response_model with the agent if you set structured_output to True, or leave it off (it will default to true with a response_model) you will get schema error about in my case is the sequentialthinking MCP tool like so: 
openai.BadRequestError: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "Invalid schema for function 'sequentialthinking': In context=(), 'additionalProperties' is required to be supplied and to be false.", 'type': 'invalid_request_error', 'param': 'tools[10].function.parameters', 'code': 'invalid_function_parameters'}}

## Steps to Reproduce
Create an agent with MCP tools, in this case sequentialthinking is easy enough, and then set a response_model. 

NOTE: If you set json_mode on it will disabled structured_output for the agent and it works and the pydantic model gets hydrated by the agent. 

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
Provide relevant agent configuration.    async with MCPTools(f"npx @modelcontextprotocol/server-sequential-thinking") as mcp_tools:
        agent = Agent(
            model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4.1-mini"),
            storage=SqliteStorage(table_name="heinz_agent"),

issues.title: [Bug]
issues.body:
# Description
Double quotes in Oracle SQL queries

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Run similar query from Agent UI: Give me 5 products with 100% match on 10th April 2025
2. LLama gives below
SQL Query:  SELECT PRODUCT FROM PRODUCT_SUMMARY WHERE MATCH_PERCENT = 100 AND RUN_DATE = '10-Apr-25'
3.  SQLTools prints below error  in log
ERROR    Error running query: (cx_Oracle.DatabaseError) ORA-00904: "10-Apr-25": invalid identifier
         [SQL: SELECT PRODUCT  FROM PRODUCT_SUMMARY WHERE MATCH_PERCENT = 100 AND RUN_DATE = "10-Apr-25"]
         (Background on this error at:  https://sqlalche.me/e/20/4xp6)


## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
sql_tools = SQLTools(
    db_engine=engine,
    tables=allowed_tables,
    schema="CUSTOM_SCHEMA",
)
sql_tools.add_instructions = True
sql_tools.instructions = (
    "If double quotes are used in the SQL query, replace them with single quotes."
)
agent = Agent(
        name="DB Analysis Agent",
        model=Ollama(id="llama3.2:3b-instruct-q8_0"),
        markdown=True,
        show_tool_calls=True,
        add_history_to_messages=True,
        system_message=system_prompt,
        tools=[sql_tools],
    )

## Expected Behavior
Double  quotes should not be there in Oracle SQL where conditions

## Actual Behavior
Python is probably changing the single quotes to double  quotes causing syntax issues while executing


## Environment
- OS: Windows 11
- Agno Version: 1.2.11
- Additional Environment Details: Python 3.12

A solve for that would be to exclude member tool definitions by setting `add_member_tools_to_system_message=False`

issues.title: [Bug] 'Please install the `semantic` extra to use this feature'
issues.body:
# Description
Using `agno.document.chunking.semantic.SemanticChunking` in Agno version 1.3.3 fails with an `ImportError` related to a missing `semantic` extra, even when using the default `OpenAIEmbedder` with model `text-embedding-3-small`. Attempting to install the suggested extra via `pip install "agno[semantic]"` results in a warning that this version does not provide the extra.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Install `agno==1.3.3` and its dependencies (including `openai`, `qdrant-client`, `python-dotenv`).
2. Create a Python script that initializes `agno.document.chunking.semantic.SemanticChunking`. This can be done directly or via a `Reader` class like `TextReader`. For example:
   ```python
   from agno.document.reader.text_reader import TextReader
   from agno.document.chunking.semantic import SemanticChunking
   # ... other imports
   text_reader = TextReader(chunk=True, chunking_strategy=SemanticChunking())
   ```
3. Ensure an OpenAI embedder (like the default `text-embedding-3-small`) is implicitly or explicitly used by `SemanticChunking`.
4. Run the script.

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
While not strictly an agent issue, the problem occurs during the setup of components often used with agents, specifically when initializing the chunking strategy:
```python
# Example from load_docs_to_qdrant.py that triggers the error:
from agno.document.reader.text_reader import TextReader
from agno.document.chunking.semantic import SemanticChunking

text_reader = TextReader(chunk=True, chunking_strategy=SemanticChunking())
```

## Expected Behavior
`SemanticChunking` should initialize successfully without errors, either by using the default `OpenAIEmbedder` or a provided compatible embedder instance. If an extra dependency is truly required, `pip install "agno[semantic]"` should successfully install it.

## Actual Behavior
The script fails during the initialization of `SemanticChunking` with the following error:
```
ImportError: ('text-embedding-3-small is not a valid embedding model', 'Please install the `semantic` extra to use this feature')
```
Attempting to install the extra dependency fails:
```
(.venv) E:\AI\RAG\Agno> .venv\Scripts\pip.exe install "agno[semantic]"
Requirement already satisfied: agno[semantic] in e:\ai\rag\agno\.venv\lib\site-packages (1.3.3)
WARNING: agno 1.3.3 does not provide the extra 'semantic'
... (other requirements satisfied) ...
```

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
```
2025-04-18 22:17:32,552 - ERROR - An error occurred during the loading process: ('text-embedding-3-small is not a valid embedding model', 'Please install the `semantic` extra to use this feature')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "E:\AI\RAG\Agno\load_docs_to_qdrant.py", line 148, in <module>
    text_reader = TextReader(chunk=True, chunking_strategy=SemanticChunking()) # Error occurs here
  File "E:\AI\RAG\Agno\.venv\Lib\site-packages\agno\document\chunking\semantic.py", line 23, in __init__
    self.chunker = SemanticChunker(
                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "E:\AI\RAG\Agno\.venv\Lib\site-packages\chonkie\chunker\semantic.py", line 142, in __init__
    raise ImportError(
ImportError: ('text-embedding-3-small is not a valid embedding model', 'Please install the `semantic` extra to use this feature')
```

## Environment
- OS: Windows 11
- Browser (if relevant): N/A
- Agno Version: 1.3.3
- External Dependency Versions: openai, qdrant-client, python-dotenv, chonkie (used internally by SemanticChunking)
- Additional Environment Details: Python 3.12.6

## Additional Context
The issue seems related to how optional dependencies (extras) are defined or handled in Agno v1.3.3. The error originates from the `chonkie` library when it receives the `text-embedding-3-small` model ID, but the inability to install the required `semantic` extra points to an issue within the Agno package definition itself for this version. This prevents the use of semantic chunking with the default (and potentially other) embedding models.
```
issues.author: gabelul

from agno.knowledge.pdf_url import PDFUrlKnowledgeBase
from agn

issues.body:
As mentioned in the title, I was testing the example from https://docs.agno.com/teams/coordinate, but using the aprint_response method instead. In some random cases, the 'Function transfer_task_to_member not found' error appears, causing the program to fail.

Here's my code:
```python
import asyncio

from dotenv import load_dotenv
from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.deepseek import DeepSeek
from agno.team import Team
from agno.tools.duckduckgo import DuckDuckGoTools

load_dotenv("../.env")

model = DeepSeek(
    temperature=0.01
)

researcher = Agent(
    name="Researcher",
    role="Expert at finding information",
    tools=[DuckDuckGoTools()],
    model=model
)

writer = Agent(
    name="Writer",
    role="Expert at writing clear, engaging content",
    model=model
)

content_team = Team(
    name="Content Team",
    mode="coordinate",
    members=[researcher, writer],
    instructions="You are a team of researchers and writers that work together to create high-quality content.",
    model=model,
    markdown=True,
    debug_mode=True
)


async def main():
    await content_team.aprint_response(
        "Create a short article about quantum computing",
        stream=True
    )


if __name__ == "__main__":

import asyncio
from pathlib import Path
from textwrap import dedent
from fastmcp import FastMCP, Client
from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.tools.mcp import MCPTools,MultiMCPTools
from mcp import StdioServerParameters

import os 
os.environ["DEEPSEEK_API_KEY"] = "sk-**"



model = DeepSeek()

mcp_config = {
        "mcpServers": {
            "scanpy-mcp": {
                "command": "scanpy-mcp",
                "args": ["run"],
            }
        }
    }

async def create_sub_agent(name, role, tools, tool_prefix, mcp_session, model):
    tool_names = [i.name for i in tools if i.name.startswith(tool_prefix)]
    tool_deses = [i.description for i in tools if i.name in tool_names]
    
    # Define a template for each tool
    tool_template = """
    <tool>
    <name>{name}</name>
    <description>{desc}</description>
    </tool>"""
    
    # Generate XML using template and join
    tools_xml = "\n".join([
        tool_template.format(name=name, desc=desc)
        for name, desc in zip(tool_names, tool_deses)
    ])
    
    description = f"""
    You are a member of bioinformatics team. You have following tools:    
    {tools_xml}
    """
    description=""
    async with MCPTools(
        session=mcp_session, include_tools=tool_names
    ) as mcp_tools:
        agent = Agent(
            name=name,
            role=role,
            model=model,
            tools=[mcp_tools],
            description=description,
            show_tool_calls=True,
            debug_mode=True,
            monitoring=True  
        )
        return agent


async def run_agent(message: str) -> None:
    """Run the filesystem agent with the given message."""
    client = Client(mcp_config)
    async with client:
        tools = await client.list_tools()
      
        io_agent = await create_sub_agent(
            "IO_Agent", "IO Module of Scanpy", tools, "io_", client.session, model
            )
        pp_agent = await create_sub_agent(
            "PP_Agent", "Preprocess Module of Scanpy", tools, "pp_", client.session, model
            )
        bio_team = Team(
            name="Bioinformatics Team",
            #mode="route",
            model=model,
            members=[io_agent, pp_agent],
            show_tool_calls=True,
            markdown=True,
            description="""
                "You are a Bioinformatics task router that directs task to the appropriate bioinformatics agent.",
            """,
            enable_agentic_context=True,
            share_member_interactions=True,
            show_members_responses=True,
            monitoring=True
        )
        await bio_team.aprint_response(message, stream=True)



if __name__ == "__main__":
    #  Basic example - exploring project license

    asyncio.run(
        run_agent(
             "read /data20T/dev/GBI-Eval/h5ad/GSE205013.h5ad, "
             "then filter cells which gene number < 200; filter genes which express < 3 cells;"      
            )
        )
```

issues.title: [Feature Request] Add Native LangSmith Integration with Structured Tracing for LLMs, Tools, and Agent Steps
issues.body:
---

###  Problem Description

Currently, LangSmith tracing with Agno only captures the **entire agent execution as a single trace**, without detailed **subtraces for LLM calls, tool use, intermediate steps, etc.** This makes it hard to debug or evaluate the performance of each part of the agent workflow (especially for multi-step chains or tool-based agents).

I've manually instrumented LangSmith using the `@traceable` decorator like this:

```python
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv, find_dotenv
from langsmith import Client, traceable
from agno.models.litellm import LiteLLM
from agno.agent import Agent

load_dotenv(find_dotenv())

client = Client(api_key=os.getenv("LANGSMITH_API_KEY"))

base_llm = LiteLLM(
    id=os.getenv("MODEL_ID"),
    name="LiteLLM",
)
agent = Agent(model=base_llm, markdown=True)

@traceable(name="AgnoAgentPrintRun", client=client)
def run_and_print(prompt: str) -> str:
    resp = agent.run(prompt)
    print(resp.content)
    return resp.content

if __name__ == "__main__":
    run_and_print("Share a 2 sentence horror story")

```

But this only shows **one big trace**, rather than structured nested traces (e.g., parent span = agent run, child spans = LLM call, tool call, parsing, etc.).

---

###  Proposed Solution

Add **first-class LangSmith integration into Agno**, similar to how LangChain and LiteLLM support it. This could include:

* Automatically wrapping LLM calls inside Agno with `langsmith.traceable` spans.
* Tracing tool usage, intermediate steps, and reasoning phases with child spans.
* Optionally allow users to pass a `LangSmith Client` or enable tracing via environment variable.

This would provide **rich observability** for Agno agents with full step-by-step visibility in the LangSmith UI.

---

###  Alternatives Considered

* Manually wrapping every internal LLM/tool call using LangSmith‚Äôs low-level `tracer.span()` context manager.
  This is tedious and requires deep modification of Agno internals.

---

###  Additional Context

* Example from LangChain‚Äôs tracing:

  * Top-level agent call

    * LLM subtrace
    * Tool subtrace
    * Tool return handling
* Agno agent is being traced as a single block, missing this granularity.

---

###  Would you like to work on this?

* [ ] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!
* [x] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.
* [ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.

---

issues.title: [Feature Request] Need addition tool info in `RunEvent.tool_call_started` and `RunEvent.tool_call_completed` events
issues.body:
## Problem Description
Currently the tool call started / completed events look like this

```
{
  "content": "Some response from tool call as text",
  "tool_call_id": "29664839-aeb0-4fed-91b5-074d1d5c3af4",
  "tool_name": "google_search",
  "tool_args": {
    "query": "latest news about AI models"
  },
  "tool_call_error": false,
  "metrics": {
    "input_tokens": 0,
    "output_tokens": 0,
    "total_tokens": 0,
    "audio_tokens": 0,
    "input_audio_tokens": 0,
    "output_audio_tokens": 0,
    "cached_tokens": 0,
    "reasoning_tokens": 0,
    "prompt_tokens": 0,
    "completion_tokens": 0,
    "prompt_tokens_details": null,
    "completion_tokens_details": null,
    "additional_metrics": null,
    "time": 0.3089268329786137,
    "time_to_first_token": null,
    "timer": null
  },
  "created_at": 1746913738
}
```

Can we have few more items added to this which would be helpful to show tool call details in UI.
Items like:
- Tool call display name -- Human readable tool call name
- Tool call short description -- Human readable one liner to tell what the tool do
- Description for each arg -- Human readable one liner description of each arg

----

Also, is it possible to get tool call response (content key) as human readable markdown, right now it is raw response from tool ? not super important, but good if it is configurable and can be provided out of box. Anyway, this can be implemented in app, after capturing the tool call completed event.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Streamable HTTP transport support in MCPTools
issues.body:
## Problem Description
`MCPTools` still ships only **STDIO** / **SSE**, it needs to also support **STREAMABLE-HTTP**.  
Modern hosts (Cloudflare Workers, Lambda, etc.) throttle long-lived SSE; agents can‚Äôt stream reliably.  
The **Python SDK** already merged Streamable HTTP (`src/mcp/transports/streamable_http.py`) in PR [#641](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/641).

## Proposed Solution
Allow `transport="streamable-http"` in `MCPTools(...)`, exposing the same params as the SDK for drop-in parity, with `mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client` ([permalink](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/blob/ed25167fa5d715733437996682e20c24470e8177/src/mcp/client/streamable_http.py#L411C11-L411C32)).

## Alternatives Considered
No alternatives observed - just keeping up with mcp development.

## Additional context
* **Spec** ‚Äì Streamable HTTP is part of MCP spec 2025-03-26 ([changelog](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/modelcontextprotocol/blob/7f1b9e5a683acdaf574dc4e565763db75c70c57a/docs/specification/2025-03-26/changelog.mdx#L14))
* **Reference impl & PR** ‚Äì python-sdk PR [#641](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/641). (‚ÄúStreamable HTTP ‚Äì improve usability, auth‚Äù).


## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
**[X] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[ ] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

**Note:** I‚Äôve already started implementation on branch `feat/streamable-http` on my fork.  
I‚Äôll self-assign this issue and open a **draft pull request** - I'll try on this weekend.

issues.title: Encoding Support for Emojis in save_response_to_file Method for Makrdown
issues.body:
https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blame/62ae18304c4d74375df273478fb0beff04e2a718/libs/agno/agno/agent/agent.py#L2877

Hi Team,

First, I want to express my appreciation for your excellent library‚ÄîI've been using it extensively in my product development, and it's been a great help!

However, I‚Äôve encountered an issue when saving responses in markdown format that contain emojis. The file doesn't get saved due to an encoding issue when using the save_response_to_file method.

Here‚Äôs the code I am using:

```
research_scholar = Agent(
    model=OpenAILike(id="gpt-4o", base_url='http://localhost:1234/v1' ,api_key='lm'),
    save_response_to_file="tmp/{message}.md",
    instructions= """Write response using emojis """,
    stream=True,
    markdown=True
)
```

The issue seems to stem from the encoding used when writing the response content to the file. The problem was resolved on my end when I modified this line: `fn_path.write_text(self.run_response.content)` to `fn_path.write_text(self.run_response.content, encoding="utf-8")`


After adding UTF-8 encoding, the emojis were saved correctly. I would like to suggest that you consider providing built-in support for encoding options in the save_response_to_file method, as this would resolve the issue for all users who deal with non-ASCII characters such as emojis.

Thank you for your consideration, and I look forward to any updates or fixes to address this


Note: Also let me know in case you guys want me to raise the pull request with this fix, though this is small.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Replace Markdown Issue Templates with YAML Forms
issues.body:
## Problem Description

I find that the current Markdown-based issue templates (`bug_report.md`, `feature_request.md`) lack the structure and guidance offered by GitHub's newer **YAML Issue Forms**. This can lead to contributors submitting issues that are missing key information or are formatted inconsistently, making it harder for maintainers to quickly understand and act on them.

---

## Proposed Solution

My ideal solution is to **replace the existing Markdown templates with YAML Issue Forms**. This involves:

- Creating `bug-report.yml` with specific fields (e.g., *Description*, *Steps to Reproduce*, *Environment*, etc.) using elements like `textarea`, `input`, and `markdown` for clear guidance and structure.
- Creating `feature-request.yml` similarly, with fields like *Problem Description*, *Proposed Solution*, and *Alternatives*.
- Adding `config.yml` to disable blank issues and guide users towards the new forms.
- Deleting the old `bug_report.md` and `feature_request.md` files.

This will provide a more guided and structured experience for users submitting issues, ensuring necessary details are captured consistently.

---

## Alternatives Considered

The main alternative is to keep the existing Markdown templates. However, this means missing out on the benefits of structured input fields, required field validation, and the overall improved user experience that YAML Issue Forms provide.

---

## Additional Context

- This change aligns with current GitHub best practices for managing issue templates.
- It will help maintainers by ensuring more complete and consistently formatted bug reports and feature requests.
- The implementation for this proposal has already been completed on the `feature/issue-forms` branch.

---

## Would You Like to Work on This?

- [X] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it! (The changes are already implemented on the `feature/issue-forms` branch.)

issues.title: Add workflow to enforce PR title and description standards
issues.body:
## Problem Description
I often find it frustrating when reviewing pull requests that have vague titles like "updates" or "fixed stuff", or when PRs don't clearly link to the issue they are addressing. This makes the commit history harder to scan and understand, and it complicates tracking which problems are being solved by which contributions, especially as the project grows. Manually reminding contributors about formatting and linking issues takes up valuable reviewer time.

## Proposed Solution
Implement an automated check using a GitHub Actions workflow (`.github/workflows/pr-lint.yml`) that runs on every pull request event (opened, edited, synchronize). This workflow enforces two key standards:

1. **PR Title Format:** Ensures the pull request title starts with a valid type tag enclosed in square brackets, followed by a space and a concise subject.  
   Example: `[feat] Add new login endpoint`  
   Valid tags include: `[feat]`, `[fix]`, `[docs]`, `[test]`, `[refactor]`, `[build]`, `[ci]`, `[chore]`, `[perf]`, `[style]`, `[revert]`.

2. **Linked Issue:** Verifies that the pull request description includes a reference to a tracked issue using keywords like `fixes #<issue_number>`, `closes #<issue_number>`, or `resolves #<issue_number>`.

If either check fails, the workflow will fail and provide clear instructions to the contributor on what needs to be corrected before the PR can be merged.

## Alternatives Considered
The primary alternative is relying on manual enforcement by reviewers or maintainers. However, this is time-consuming, error-prone, and doesn't scale well as the project grows. Automating the check ensures consistent adherence to standards and allows reviewers to focus on the code itself rather than administrative details.

## Additional context
The contribution guidelines in `CONTRIBUTING.md` have been updated to reflect these new requirements. They provide clear instructions for contributors and link directly to the workflow file to ensure transparency and understanding.

## Would you like to work on this?
**[X] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it! (In fact, the workflow and documentation updates have already been implemented.)**
**[ ] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

issues.title: `AgentKnowledge` ignores custom `chunking_strategy` and always uses `FixedSizeChunking` in `v1.4.5`
issues.body:
# Description
In version 1.4.5, the AgentKnowledge component is skipping the provided chunking_strategy and defaulting to FixedSizeChunking in all cases. This behavior was not present in earlier versions.

## Steps to Reproduce
```py
from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.document.chunking.semantic import SemanticChunking
from agno.knowledge.pdf_url import PDFUrlKnowledgeBase
from agno.vectordb.pgvector import PgVector

db_url = "postgresql+psycopg://ai:ai@localhost:5532/ai"

knowledge_base = PDFUrlKnowledgeBase(
    urls=["https://agno-public.s3.amazonaws.com/recipes/ThaiRecipes.pdf"],
    vector_db=PgVector(table_name="recipes_semantic_chunking", db_url=db_url),
    chunking_strategy=SemanticChunking(),
)
knowledge_base.load(recreate=False)  # Comment out after first run

agent = Agent(
    knowledge_base=knowledge_base,
    search_knowledge=True,
)

agent.print_response("How to make Thai curry?", markdown=True)
```
## What I Expected:
The PDF should be chunked using the SemanticChunking strategy.

## What Actually Happened:
Despite specifying SemanticChunking(), the system falls back to FixedSizeChunking and ignores the custom strategy.

## Environment
- OS: Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS
- Agno Version: 1.4.5
- Additional Environment Details: Python 3.12.9

## Additional Context
This issue only occurs in version 1.4.5. Downgrading to an earlier release restores the expected behavior.
issues.author: Khalid1G

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body: @Khalid1G Apologies, this has been fixed in 1.4.6.

issues.title: [Success Story] Compere: A Multi-Agent System on Agno Framework (Gemini 2.5 repo-level code generation)
issues.body:
I was using Gemini 2.5 in AI Studio, provided it with the required docs and the following task: "Propose an implementation of Compere (I1) and its team using Agno" ü•≥

Please create a single document capturing the whole success story ‚ú®

[YouTube|NotebookLM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lh0TlADJ3NQ)

---

## Problem Description
The Agno framework, specifically in the streaming path (response_stream in Model.base), is executing the tool call logic. When it encounters the async def get_response_draft_from_fizz tool, it calls the function but fails to await the resulting coroutine object. Instead of getting the string result after awaiting, it takes the coroutine object itself and tries to put it into the content field of the tool message. Since a coroutine object is neither a string nor a list, the Pydantic validation for the Message class fails.

This is likely an issue within the agno framework's handling of async def tools specifically during streaming responses. The non-streaming path might handle it correctly, but the streaming logic seems to miss the necessary await.

## Proposed Solution
This requires a fix within the agno library itself to ensure that when a tool function defined with async def is executed during a streaming response, the returned coroutine is correctly awaited before its result is processed and packaged into the tool message.

## Alternatives Considered
As a temporary workaround in your script (though it sacrifices the benefits of async IO for the tools), you could try making the tool functions synchronous:

Change async def to def for all the tool functions (consult_fozz, delegate_to_qllickfizz, etc.).

Change await persona.arun(...) to persona.run(...) inside each tool function.

Change compere.cli_app(stream=True) - you might need to test if compere.run(...) (non-async, non-stream) works without error, or if compere.cli_app(stream=True) still functions correctly with sync tools.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Enhanced Structured Output Support in Agent Class
issues.body:
# Feature Request: Enhanced Structured Output Support in Agent Class

## Problem Description

Currently, the `agno.Agent` class only accepts Pydantic `BaseModel` for the `response_model` parameter. This limits flexibility when working with dynamic output structures or when using simpler string-based formats.

Example:
```python
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model='gemini-2.0-flash-001',
    contents='Give me information for the United States.',
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(
        response_mime_type='application/json',
        response_schema={
            'required': [
                'name',
                'population',
                'capital',
                'continent',
                'gdp',
                'official_language',
                'total_area_sq_mi',
            ],
            'properties': {
                'name': {'type': 'STRING'},
                'population': {'type': 'INTEGER'},
                'capital': {'type': 'STRING'},
                'continent': {'type': 'STRING'},
                'gdp': {'type': 'INTEGER'},
                'official_language': {'type': 'STRING'},
                'total_area_sq_mi': {'type': 'INTEGER'},
            },
            'type': 'OBJECT',
        },
    ),
)
```

## Proposed Solution

Enhance the `response_model` parameter to accept either:
- A Pydantic `BaseModel` type (current behavior)
- A string template or identifier

This would allow the Agent to handle structured outputs in different ways depending on the type provided:
- When given a `BaseModel`, use the existing Pydantic validation
- When given a string option, implement an alternative processing approach

## Benefits

1. Provides more flexibility for runtime-defined output structures
2. Reduces the need for defining static Pydantic models for every use case
3. Simplifies working with dynamic structures derived from configuration

## Implementation Considerations

The change would require adding type checking for the `response_model` parameter and implementing conditional logic based on the provided type. The existing functionality would remain unchanged for backward compatibility.

### Would you like to work on this?

We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
**[ ] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[x ] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**
issues.author: diefergil

comments.author: pritipsingh
comments.body:
Thanks for raising this, @diefergil !

It's a good point ‚Äî we can definitely consider expanding support for other response formats in the future. At the moment, application/json seems to be mainly supported by Gemini, whereas using a Pydantic class offers a more consistent and standard approach acro

https://docs.agno.com/examples/concepts/storage/team_storage/mongodb

hn_researcher = Agent(
    name="HackerNews Researcher",
    model=OpenAIChat("gpt-4o"),
    role="Gets top stories from hackernews.",
    tools=[HackerNewsTools()],
)

    name="Web Searcher",

)


hn_team = Team(

issues.title: `MemoryV2` Messages are not stored in storage
issues.body:
# Description
If I have a team with `num_of_interactions_from_history` as any number larger than 3, ever subsequent call to the model will only have 3 messages. 

Here's a test I built to double check this:
```
import os
import tempfile
import uuid

import pytest

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.memory.v2.db.sqlite import SqliteMemoryDb
from agno.memory.v2.memory import Memory
from agno.models.anthropic.claude import Claude
from agno.models.openai.chat import OpenAIChat
from agno.storage.sqlite import SqliteStorage
from agno.team.team import Team


@pytest.fixture
def temp_storage_db_file():
    """Create a temporary SQLite database file for team storage testing."""
    with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(suffix=".db", delete=False) as temp_file:
        db_path = temp_file.name

    yield db_path

    # Clean up the temporary file after the test
    if os.path.exists(db_path):
        os.unlink(db_path)


@pytest.fixture
def temp_memory_db_file():
    """Create a temporary SQLite database file for memory testing."""
    with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(suffix=".db", delete=False) as temp_file:
        db_path = temp_file.name

    yield db_path

    # Clean up the temporary file after the test
    if os.path.exists(db_path):
        os.unlink(db_path)


@pytest.fixture
def team_storage(temp_storage_db_file):
    """Create a SQLite storage for team sessions."""
    # Use a unique table name for each test run
    table_name = f"team_sessions_{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"
    storage = SqliteStorage(table_name=table_name, db_file=temp_storage_db_file, mode="team")
    storage.create()
    return storage


@pytest.fixture
def memory_db(temp_memory_db_file):
    """Create a SQLite memory database for testing."""
    db = SqliteMemoryDb(db_file=temp_memory_db_file)
    db.create()
    return db


@pytest.fixture
def memory(memory_db):
    """Create a Memory instance for testing."""
    return Memory(model=Claude(id="claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022"), db=memory_db)




@pytest.fixture
def route_team(team_storage, memory):
    """Create a route team with storage and memory for testing."""
    return Team(
        name="Route Team",
        mode="collaborate",
        model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
        members=[],
        storage=team_storage,
        memory=memory,
        enable_user_memories=True,
        num_of_interactions_from_history=10,
        num_history_runs=10,
    )


@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_run_history_persistence(route_team, team_storage, memory):
    """Test that all runs within a session are persisted in storage."""
    user_id = "test_persistence_user@example.com"
    session_id = "test_persistence_session"
    num_turns = 5

    # Clear memory for this specific test case
    memory.clear()

    # Perform multiple turns
    conversation_messages = [
        "What's the weather like today?",
        "What about tomorrow?",
        "Any recommendations for indoor activities?",
        "Search for nearby museums.",
        "Which one has the best reviews?",
    ]

    assert len(conversation_messages) == num_turns

    for i, msg in enumerate(conversation_messages):
        print(f"Turn {i+1}: {msg}")
        await route_team.arun(msg, user_id=user_id, session_id=session_id)
        # Optional: Check memory state in RAM after each turn if needed for debugging
        # print(f"Runs in memory after turn {i+1}: {len(memory.runs.get(session_id, []))}")

    # Verify the stored session data after all turns
    team_session = team_storage.read(session_id=session_id)


    stored_memory_data = team_session.memory
    assert stored_memory_data is not None, "Memory data not found in stored session."
    print(f"Stored memory data: {stored_memory_data}")
    stored_runs = stored_memory_data["runs"]
    assert isinstance(stored_runs, list), "Stored runs data is not a list."


    first_user_message_content = stored_runs[0]['messages'][1]['content']
    assert first_user_message_content == conversation_messages[0]
```

This should pass but it fails and the "first_user_message" is always `Any recommendations for indoor activities?`

## Additional Context
Discord link: https://discord.com/channels/965734768803192842/1369017040194502897
issues.author: DannyAziz

comments.author: DannyAziz

import tempfile
import uuid

import pytest

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.memory.v2.db.sqlite import SqliteMemoryDb
from agno.memory.v2.memory import Memory
from agn

issues.body:
# Description
Simple agent run fails with Llama API from Meta.

## Test agent script:
```
from dotenv  import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

from agno.agent import Agent
# from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
# from agno.models.google import Gemini
from agno.models.meta import Llama
from agno.tools.googlesearch import GoogleSearchTools
from agno.tools.yfinance import YFinanceTools
from agno.tools.crawl4ai import Crawl4aiTools
from agno.storage.sqlite import SqliteStorage

agent_storage = SqliteStorage(
    table_name="agent_sessions",
    db_file="tmp/persistent_memory.db",
)

sample_agent = Agent(
    name="agno_agent",
    description="You are a helpful assistant who can search web, crawl page contents and also search financial information using given tools to achieve the given user goal.",
    # model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
    # model=Gemini(id="gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17"),  # or any other supported model
    model=Llama(id="Llama-4-Maverick-17B-128E-Instruct-FP8"),
    instructions=[
        "If user input is not sufficent, ask user relevant questions / clarifications",
        "To search the web, use google search tool.",
        "To crawl the pages use crawl4ai tools",
        "To get financial information about companies, use YFinance tools"
    ],
    storage=agent_storage,
    tools=[
        GoogleSearchTools(),
        YFinanceTools(enable_all=True),
        Crawl4aiTools(max_length=5000)
    ],
    stream_intermediate_steps=True,
    add_datetime_to_instructions=True,
    debug_mode=True
)

user_prompt = "whats the latest news about China"
for res in sample_agent.run(user_prompt, stream=True):
    print(f"Response Type: {res.event}")
    print(f"Tools: {res.tools}")
    # print(f"Messages: {res.messages}")

issues.title: [Bug] Session metrics not recorded (all values are null or 0)
issues.body:
# Description
When I configure the agent with a custom memory object using PostgresMemoryDb, the session metrics are all returned as 0 or None, and no metrics appear to be saved to the database. However, if I remove the memory=memory parameter, everything works as expected and complete metrics are recorded.

This seems to indicate a bug related to how memory is handled or interferes with session metric recording.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Initialize PostgresMemoryDb and Memory:
```
memory_db = PostgresMemoryDb(table_name="memory", db_url=db_url)
memory = Memory(db=memory_db)
```

2. Create the agent with memory=memory:
```
agent = Agent(
    name="Web Agent",
    role="Search the web for information",
    agent_id="web-agent",
    model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o"),
    tools=[DuckDuckGoTools()],
    instructions=[
        "Break down the users request into 2-3 different searches.",
        "Always include sources",
    ],
    storage=storage,
    memory=memory, # HERE THE PROBLEM
    enable_agentic_memory=True,
    enable_session_summaries=True,
    add_datetime_to_instructions=True,
    markdown=True,
)
```

3. Run a request:

```
agent.print_response("Share news about Apple", stream=True)
print(agent.session_metrics)

```

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
```
enable_agentic_memory=True
enable_session_summaries=True
memory=Memory(db=PostgresMemoryDb(...))
```

## Expected Behavior
Session metrics like input_tokens, output_tokens, total_tokens, and timestamps should be populated and saved.
`SessionMetrics(input_tokens=1138, output_tokens=545, total_tokens=1683, audio_tokens=0, input_audio_tokens=0, output_audio_tokens=0, cached_tokens=0, reasoning_tokens=0, prompt_tokens=1138, completion_tokens=545, prompt_tokens_details={'audio_tokens': 0, 'cached_tokens': 0}, completion_tokens_details={'accepted_prediction_tokens': 0, 'audio_tokens': 0, 'reasoning_tokens': 0, 'rejected_prediction_tokens': 0}, additional_metrics=None, time=25.48284649901325, time_to_first_token=2.621255750011187, timer=None)`


## Actual Behavior
All session metrics return null values:
`SessionMetrics(input_tokens=0, output_tokens=0, total_tokens=0, audio_tokens=0, input_audio_tokens=0, output_audio_tokens=0, cached_tokens=0, reasoning_tokens=0, prompt_tokens=0, completion_tokens=0, prompt_tokens_details=None, completion_tokens_details=None, additional_metrics=None, time=None, time_to_first_token=None, timer=None)`

This occurs only when a memory object is explicitly set. Without it, metrics populate correctly.



## Environment
Agno Version: (v1.4.1)

issues.title: [Bug] MCP Tool Calls Fail Due to Extraneous Parameters in Requests
issues.body:
## Bug Report: MCP Tool Calls Fail Due to Extraneous Parameters in Requests

### Issue description
When calling Supabase MCP tools like `execute_sql` and `list_tables`, requests fail with a ZodError indicating unrecognized keys in the request object. The error consistently identifies `tool_description` as an unrecognized parameter that should not be included in the request.

### Error message
```
ERROR Failed to call MCP tool 'execute_sql': Error from MCP tool 'execute_sql': 
[TextContent(type='text', text='{"error":{"name":"ZodError","message":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"code\\": \\"unrecognized_keys\\",\\n    \\"keys\\": [\\n      \\"tool_description\\"\\n    ],\\n    \\"path\\": [],\\n    \\"message\\": \\"Unrecognized key(s) in object: \'tool_description\'\\"\\n  }\\n]"}}', annotations=None)]
```

### Root cause
In `agno/utils/mcp.py`, the `get_entrypoint_for_tool` function creates a partial function that passes the `tool_description` parameter to every tool call:

```python
return partial(call_tool, tool_name=tool.name, tool_description=tool.description)
```

This parameter is not expected by the MCP API schema for Supabase tools, causing validation errors.

### Current workaround
Added a filtering mechanism in the `call_tool` function to remove the extraneous parameters:

```python
tool_params = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in ['tool_description', 'tool_name']}
result: CallToolResult = await session.call_tool(tool_name, tool_params)
```

### Suggested fix
Remove the `tool_description` parameter from the partial function declaration:

```python
# Change this line
return partial(call_tool, tool_name=tool.name, tool_description=tool.description)

# To this
return partial(call_tool, tool_name=tool.name)
```

This is a cleaner solution than filtering parameters inside the function, as it avoids passing unnecessary data in the first place.

### Environment
- Python version: 3.12
- agno version: 1.4.3
- mcp version: 1.7.1
issues.author: moiraphill

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body: Thanks for raising! PR out to fix.

comments.body: This has been merged. Releasing asap

issues.title: [Feature Request] Add tool response for `ToolCallCompleted` Event
issues.body:
## Problem Description
In current implementation, on tool call completion we get `role`, `tool_name` and `tool_args` (and `tool_call_id` although that is always `None`), but we don't get tool response. We want tool response also as developers may want to show it to user in some cases.

Also as mentioned above, I observed that `tool_call_id` is always `None`, so that may be a bug too.

Here is the sample code to reproduce it:
```
from logging import debug
from agno import tools
from dotenv  import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.models.google import Gemini
from agno.models.openrouter import OpenRouter
from agno.models.groq import Groq
from agno.tools.googlesearch import GoogleSearchTools
from agno.tools.yfinance import YFinanceTools
from agno.tools.crawl4ai import Crawl4aiTools
from agno.storage.sqlite import SqliteStorage
from agno.utils.pprint import pprint_run_response
from agno.tools import FunctionCall, tool
from markitdown import MarkItDown

agent_storage = SqliteStorage(
    table_name="agent_sessions",
    db_file="tmp/persistent_memory.db",
)

sample_agent = Agent(
    name="agno_agent",
    description="You are a helpful assistant who can search web, crawl page contents and also search financial information using given tools to achieve the given user goal.",
    # model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
    model=Gemini(id="gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17"),  # or any other supported model
    instructions=[
        "If user input is not sufficent, ask user relevant questions / clarifications",
        "To search the web, use google search tool.",
        "To crawl the pages use crawl4ai tools",
        "To get financial information about companies, use YFinance tools"
    ],
    storage=agent_storage,
    tools=[
        GoogleSearchTools(),
        YFinanceTools(enable_all=True),
        Crawl4aiTools(max_length=5000)
    ],
    # reasoning=True,
    stream_intermediate_steps=True,
    add_datetime_to_instructions=True,
    debug_mode=True
)

user_prompt = "whats the latest news about China"
for res in sample_agent.run(user_prompt, stream=True):
    print(f"Response Type: {res.event}, Tools: {res.tools}")
```

Here is the output. Please specifically look at `ToolCallCompleted` event.

Response Type: ToolCallCompleted, Tools: [{'role': 'tool', 'tool_call_id': None, 'tool_name': 'google_search', 'tool_args': {'query': 'latest news about China', 'language': 'en'}}]
