issues.title: [Bug] Description and Instructions attributes of Agents are ignored
issues.body:
# Description
Agent is not respecting prompts included in **Description** or **Instructions** attributes.

According to documentation, Description attribute works in that way:
`A description of the Agent that is added to the start of the system message`

But I'm not able to make it work. When I add agent instructions, Agent response is not following them. It only does when manually concatenating in the system_message.

## Steps to Reproduce
```
agent = Agent(
                model=AwsBedrock(
                    id="anthropic.claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620-v1:0", session=self.session
                ),
                system_message=command.system_instruction
                description=command.client_instruction, # Ignores this description. 
                description=command.client_instruction, # Ignores this instruction. 
                response_model=Asset,
            )
```

```
agent = Agent(
                model=AwsBedrock(
                    id="anthropic.claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620-v1:0", session=self.session
                ),
                system_message=command.system_instruction
                + "\n"
                + command.client_instruction,  # That way respects the instruction
                response_model=Asset,
            )
```

## Expected Behavior
I was expecting the description or instruction, to go into the system message like described in the documentation, and not having to manually concatenate.

Is it again a model issue? Is it working for you as expected using different models/providers than me?

## Environment
- OS:  macOS
- Agno Version: 1.3.1
- Additional Environment Details: (e.g., Python 3.10)
issues.author: marcsc3

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body:
@marcsc3 We use `description`, `instructions` and other agent parameters to build up the `system_message` that is sent to the model. If you provide `system_message` manually like you are doing, it would use that system message in its entirety and not add anything else. 

I updated the information in

issues.title: [Bug] coroutine 'AwsBedrock.ainvoke_stream' was never awaited
issues.body:
# Description

The playground does not work with AWS Bedrock. It fails with a `coroutine was never awaited` error.

## Steps to Reproduce

```
pip install fastapi[standard]==0.115.12 agno==1.4.2 boto3==1.38.5
```
```py
from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.aws import AwsBedrock
from agno.playground import Playground, serve_playground_app

AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = ""
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY = ""
AWS_REGION = ""

agent = Agent(
    name="Agent",
    markdown=True,

    model=AwsBedrock(
        id="anthropic.claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620-v1:0",
        aws_access_key_id=AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID,
        aws_secret_access_key=AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY,
        aws_region=AWS_REGION,
    ),

    show_tool_calls=True,
    debug_mode=True,
)

app = Playground(agents=[agent]).get_app()
if __name__ == '__main__':
    serve_playground_app("main:app", reload=True)
```
```sh
ag setup
```

Go to the Playground and prompt the agent with something.

## Expected Behavior

It should output the answer.

## Actual Behavior

In the console this gets printed:
```
.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/agno/models/base.py:586: RuntimeWarning: coroutine 'AwsBedrock.ainvoke_stream' was never awaited
  async for response_delta in self.ainvoke_stream(messages=messages):  # type: ignore
```
In the UI this is shown:
```
Oops! Something went wrong while streaming. 'async for' requires an object with __aiter__ method, got coroutine
```

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cf7e0c78-9556-4ba0-9531-45bdc67085b8

## Environment
- OS: NixOS (Linux)
- Agno Version: 1.4.2
- External Dependency Versions: `fastapi[standard]==0.115.12 boto3==1.38.5`
- Additional Environment Details: Python 3.12.9
issues.author: TheDevMinerTV

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body:
Hi @TheDevMinerTV 
Unfortunately we don't support async with AWSBedrock. You can make it work with playground by saying `app = Playground(agents=[agent]).get_app(use_async=False)`

comments.author: TheDevMinerTV
comments.body: Adding a more helpful error message or putting a warning on the website for this would be good.

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body: Thanks for the suggestion. I added a warning to the docs.

    db_url=db_url,
)

                "- Very important: when asked to open the browser, ALWAYS use "functions.browser_navigate" tool to open the browser and do not navigate anywhere"
            """
            ),

            # model=Gemini(
            # id="gemini-2.0-flash",
            # ),

            # Auto-runs MemoryManager after each user message
            enable_user_memories=True,
            # Creates and stores session summaries
            enable_session_summaries=True,
            # Gives agent a tool to manage user memories
            enable_agentic_memory=True,
            # Allow agent to read full history
            read_chat_history=True,
            # Add chat history to messages
            add_history_to_messages=True,
            # Include last 3 runs
            num_history_runs=3,
            # Include last 3 responses
            num_history_responses=3,
            read_tool_call_history=True,
            # helps the agent maintain temporal awareness by including the

            # useful when the agent needs to provide time-sensitive responses

issues.title: o3 and o4-mini with tools doesn't work
issues.body:
# Description
o3 and o4-mini fail to work with tools, results in this error:
```
Item 'fc_680a59708edc8192919fa6d8deece8d809adcab1a5183613' of type 'function_call' was provided without its required
```

## Steps to Reproduce
Small example agent:
```
agent = Agent(
        model=OpenAIResponses(id="o3"),
        tools=[YFinanceTools(cache_results=True)],
        show_tool_calls=True,
        markdown=True,
        telemetry=False,
        monitoring=False,
    )

    response = agent.run("What is the current price of TSLA?")
```

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
Provided above

## Expected Behavior
Should pass the tool call result to the model and get a final response

## Actual Behavior
Tool call response is passed back to the model and throws errors from the API

## Possible Solutions (optional)
As called out in this Discord message: https://discord.com/channels/965734768803192842/1365051310977847518

it's because o3 and o4-mini need all of their reasoning passed back to them in subsequent calls, espically for tool calling

Using the openai SDK I was able to fix this by doing this:
messages.extend(response.output)

confirmed via the openAI docs: https://arc.net/l/quote/dldicbme
issues.author: DannyAziz

```py

from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.tools.yfinance import YFinanceTools

agent = Agent(model=O

issues.body:
# Description
When agent is configured to run with Gemini models, the `tool_call_id` is always `None` and as a result the `content` / response of the tool call is also missing in in `ToolCallCompleted` event.

Works fine with OpenAI models.

Here is the agent script:
```
from logging import debug
from agno import tools
from dotenv  import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.models.google import Gemini
from agno.models.openrouter import OpenRouter
from agno.models.groq import Groq
from agno.tools.googlesearch import GoogleSearchTools
from agno.tools.yfinance import YFinanceTools
from agno.tools.crawl4ai import Crawl4aiTools
from agno.storage.sqlite import SqliteStorage
from agno.utils.pprint import pprint_run_response
from agno.tools import FunctionCall, tool
from markitdown import MarkItDown

agent_storage = SqliteStorage(
    table_name="agent_sessions",
    db_file="tmp/persistent_memory.db",
)

sample_agent = Agent(
    name="agno_agent",
    description="You are a helpful assistant who can search web, crawl page contents and also search financial information using given tools to achieve the given user goal.",
    # model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
    model=Gemini(id="gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17"),  # or any other supported model
    instructions=[
        "If user input is not sufficent, ask user relevant questions / clarifications",
        "To search the web, use google search tool.",
        "To crawl the pages use crawl4ai tools",

    storage=agent_storage,

    stream_intermediate_steps=True,
    add_datetime_to_instructions=True,

)

user_prompt = "whats the latest news about China"
for res in sample_agent.run(user_prompt, stream=True):
    print(f"Response Type: {res.event}, Tools: {res.tools}")
```

issues.title: [Bug] Inconsistency with output in agno/run/response.py
issues.body:
# Description
I found an inconsistency with how response.py handles responses in the from_dict function

## Steps to Reproduce
Not sure , Teams have memory , meaning team 1 and team 2 and master  in my setup . also all agents and teams have a shared storage .The agents have acess to the same knowledge base.

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
I have an this setup of agents : master (team agent with route mode) ,which includes these members . first team1 (team with coordinate with agents as members ) , team 2 (same as team 1 ) and finally a report generator agent . These are all members of master team

## Expected Behavior
Provide an output with sources meaning including the extra_data variable in the output as far as i can understand.

## Actual Behavior
The extra_data attribute in  RunResponse class is expected to be an instance of RunResponseExtraData, which has a to_dict() method. However, it seems that at some point, extra_data is being set to a dict instead of an instance of RunResponseExtraData. This leads to the AttributeError when to_dict() is called.

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
Not available

## Environment
- OS: (e.g. macOS, Windows 11)

- Agno Version: (e.g. v1.2.6)
- Additional Environment Details: (e.g., Python 3.11.9)

## Possible Solutions (optional)
Found a solution for this , although i do not know if it is optimal . Any ideas for a better solution to mine is welcome . So far it seems to work as intended and fixed the issue , but i am only tesing the master in terminal with print_response .

Proposed Solution by me:
in agno/run/response.py 
SOLUTION LINE 145
FROM    ->     return cls(messages=messages, **data)
TO ->
extra_data = data.pop("extra_data", None) #CUSTOM IMPLEMENTATION IN AGNO 
if extra_data is not None:
extra_data = RunResponseExtraData.from_dict(extra_data)  # Ensure it's an instance

issues.title: [Bug] Setting include_tools breaks MCPTool
issues.body:
# Description
Setting include_tools breaks MCPTool

## Steps to Reproduce
```
server_params = MCPStdioParams(
            command="docker",
            args=[
                "run",
                "-i",
                "--rm",
                "--mount",
                f"type=bind,src={tmp_path},dst=/projects",
                "mcp/filesystem",
                "/projects",
            ],
            tools=[
                "write_file",
                "read_file"
            ],
        ),
MCPTools(
            command=server_params,
            include_tools=["write_file"],
            env={**os.environ},
  )
```

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
n/a

## Expected Behavior
No crash

## Actual Behavior

```
            if include_tools:
                missing_includes = set(include_tools) - available_tools
                if missing_includes:
>                   raise ValueError(f"Included tool(s) not present in the toolkit: {', '.join(missing_includes)}")
E                   ValueError: Included tool(s) not present in the toolkit: write_file

.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/agno/tools/toolkit.py:51: ValueError
```

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
Include any relevant screenshots or error logs that demonstrate the issue.

## Environment
- Agno Version: 1.4.2

## Possible Solutions (optional)
The problem I think is that `MCPTools` is calling `    super().__init__(name="MCPToolkit", include_tools=include_tools, exclude_tools=exclude_tools, **kwargs)` and not passing in `tools` so then in that base class, tools is an empty list so the error happens

## Additional Context

I think some changes happened in agno 1.4 that made MCP less stable. I put a lot of work into writing a unit test on my side to check MCP functionality for filtering tools, maybe it would be a helpful thing to put into agno? https://github.com/mozilla-ai/any-agent/pull/152/files#diff-e52e4ddd58b7ef887ab03c04116e676f6280b824ab7469d5d3080e5cba4f2128

issues.title: [Feature Request] Consider enhancing AWS credentials management for Bedrock integration
issues.body:
Hi team! üëã

First, thanks for creating this amazing library - I've been enjoying using it for my multimodal agent projects.

## Problem Description

The current `boto3` client creation for Bedrock only supports hard-coded credentials and doesn't allow passing additional arguments to the Bedrock client. This creates security compliance challenges in some environments and somehow doesn't align with AWS best practices for credential management. This limitation not only restricts customization of client behavior but also limits adoption in security-conscious organizations that prohibit hardcoded credentials in code.

I understand that you already support passing a boto3 session to handle authentication, which is great. However, it might be beneficial to either allow passing a fully pre-configured client directly or enable the session parameter to accept additional `kwargs` that would be forwarded when creating the Bedrock client internally. This would provide more flexibility for configuring proxies, timeouts, retries, and other client-specific settings that many specific environments require.

Would you be open to enhancing this with more flexible credential and client options? This would be really helpful for security compliance in enterprise environments and could help drive adoption.

## Proposed Solution

### Accept a pre-configured client

```python
import boto3
from botocore.config import Config
from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.aws import AwsBedrock

model = AwsBedrock()


# Configure proxy settings
proxy_config = Config(
    proxies={
        'http': 'http://proxy.example.com:8080',
        'https': 'https://proxy.example.com:8080'
    }
)

# Create session with profile and client with proxy config
session = boto3.Session(profile_name='my-secure-profile')
custom_client = session.client(
    'bedrock-runtime', 
    region_name='us-west-2',
    config=proxy_config
)

# Pass the pre-configured client to AwsBedrock
model = AwsBedrock(id="mistral.mistral-large-2402-v1:0", bedrock_client=custom_client)

agent = Agent(
    model=model,
    markdown=True
)

# Print the response on the terminal
agent.print_response("Share a 2 sentence horror story.")
```

I'd be happy to help implement this and update the documentation if you're interested in the idea. What do you think?

## Alternatives Considered

Allow pass `kwagrs` to the client and session.

## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
**[x] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[ ] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

issues.title: [Bug] namespace parameter in vectordb.pinecone not respected
issues.body: # Description When specifying namespace in pinecone index, it is not respected and documents are upserted and doc_exist-checked in default namespace. ## Steps to Reproduce Specify namespace when initializing vectordb Do upsert of any Document Check in pinecone - the Document is in default namespace ('') ``` from agno.knowledge.website import WebsiteKnowledgeBase from agno.vectordb.pineconedb import PineconeDb from agno.utils.log import set_log_level_to_debug from os import getenv from agno.document import Document set_log_level_to_debug() url = "https://help.company.store/article/87-how-can-i-set-up-a-disclaimer-or-terms-of-conditions-for-my-customers" knowledge_base = WebsiteKnowledgeBase( urls=[url], max_depth=2, max_links=1, vector_db=PineconeDb( name="test", namespace="helpdocs", dimension=1536, api_key=getenv("PINECONE_API"), spec=dict(serverless=dict(cloud="aws", region="us-east-1")) ), ) knowledge_base.vector_db.upsert([Document( name=url, id=str(12), meta_data={"url": str(url)}, content="test content" )]) ``` ## Agent Configuration (if applicable) Not applicable ## Expected Behavior Document should be upserted in specified namespace ## Actual Behavior Document was upserted in default namespace ## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable) ## Environment - OS: Not relevant - Browser (if relevant): Not relevant - Agno Version: 1.4.1 - External Dependency Versions: pinecone==5.4.2 - Additional Environment Details: setup with provided dev script ## Possible Solutions (optional) PR fixing that here https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/pull/2973 ## Additional Context Checked Pinecone API docs for v.5.4.2 - namespace argument is supported in: index/upsert - used in agno.vectordb.pineconedb.upsert - sync requires fix, async version was already ok index/query - used in agno.vectordb.pineconedb.search - sync/async ok in existing code vectors/fetch - used in agno.vectordb.pineconedb.doc_exists - sync requires fix, async already ok vectors/update, vectors/delete, vectors/list - not used in agno.vectordb.pineconedb

issues.title: [Feature Request] Support o4-mini for reasoning
issues.body:
## Problem Description
Current, agno do not support o4-mini for reasoning.
https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/main/libs/agno/agno/reasoning/openai.py#L11

```python
def is_openai_reasoning_model(reasoning_model: Model) -> bool:
    return (
        (
            reasoning_model.__class__.__name__ == "OpenAIChat"
            or reasoning_model.__class__.__name__ == "OpenAIResponses"
            or reasoning_model.__class__.__name__ == "AzureOpenAI"
        )
        and (
            ("o3" in reasoning_model.id)
            or ("o1" in reasoning_model.id)
            or ("4.1" in reasoning_model.id)
            or ("4.5" in reasoning_model.id)
        )
    ) or (isinstance(reasoning_model, OpenAILike) and "deepseek-r1" in reasoning_model.id.lower())
```

There is a named match on this.

Error message:

`WARNING  Reasoning model: OpenAIResponses is not a native reasoning model, defaulting to manual Chain-of-Thought reasoning`

## Proposed Solution
We can have a way to users define witch model they wanna use, not a hardcoded list like this.

## Alternatives Considered
A quick solution for now is to add `o4` match and just fix it.
```python
def is_openai_reasoning_model(reasoning_model: Model) -> bool:
    return (
        (
            reasoning_model.__class__.__name__ == "OpenAIChat"
            or reasoning_model.__class__.__name__ == "OpenAIResponses"
            or reasoning_model.__class__.__name__ == "AzureOpenAI"
        )
        and (
            ("o4" in reasoning_model.id) #New o4 reasoning model
            or ("o3" in reasoning_model.id)
            or ("o1" in reasoning_model.id)
            or ("4.1" in reasoning_model.id)
            or ("4.5" in reasoning_model.id)
        )
    ) or (isinstance(reasoning_model, OpenAILike) and "deepseek-r1" in reasoning_model.id.lower())
```


## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
**[X] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[X] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

issues.title: [Bug] Silenced exceptions
issues.body:
# Description
Exception silencing in website reader is problematic. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d9c684bc-b4f0-483d-8b75-5940e8ec9107)

This means that we can not catch this exception in a higher level tool and return an appropriate error. Instead we only get a printout and then an empty list is returned. This is not just limited to this function - there is a lot of exception silencing going on in that file. 

What we should be doing instead is perhaps print a warning and then raise a CrawlError exception or something like that. Or even HTTP exception.

issues.title: [Bug] Gemini tools and response_model are incompatible
issues.body:
# Description
Gemini `tools` and `response_model` are incompatible

Currently, if you declare any tools and `response_model` argument, Gemini will throw an error saying 

```
google.genai.errors.ClientError: 400 INVALID_ARGUMENT. {'error': {'code': 400, 'message': "For controlled generation of only function calls (forced function calling), please set 'tool_config.function_calling_config.mode' field to ANY instead of populating 'response_mime_type' and 'response_schema' fields. For more details, see: https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/multimodal/function-calling#tool-config", 'status': 'INVALID_ARGUMENT'}}
```
I put the `tool_config` inside of request argument, and it doesn't work, persist the same error, but if i remove the `response_schema` and `response_mime_type` it work, but without the response schema

Scratching the code I found with that those combined arguments throw the error, I made an application with pydantic-ai and this error doesn't appear, because the `response_model` has inside of tools like `final_result` tool.

So, I can make a PR with these changes, and I want to ask, are you fine with this approach?

approach:
When you run an Agent and making the [request kwargs with tools](https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/d3cceaf34db84f57d694be3f446a976aaa80a201/libs/agno/agno/models/google/gemini.py#L283C16-L283C16)

1. check if you have `response_schema`
  - if not, dont do it anything
2. if yes
3. append from `response_schema` as a new tool called `final_result`
  - descrition: `Final result.`
  - with the parameters of the object (for now only support pydantic BaseModel)
4. remove `response_schema`
5. remove `response_mime_type`
6. ... (make the request to gemini)
7. when [parse the tools](https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/d3cceaf34db84f57d694be3f446a976aaa80a201/libs/agno/agno/models/google/gemini.py#L643C38-L643C38)
8. check the tool name has `final_result`
  - if not, dont do anythinh 
9. if so, put the answer with `json.dumps(part.function_call.args)` into `model_response.content`

I think is a little tangled to avoid the gemini error, but will work


## Steps to Reproduce

This is an example to reproduce the error

```python
import os

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.google import Gemini
from agno.tools.googlesearch import GoogleSearchTools
from agno.workflow import RunResponse
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

if os.getenv("GOOGLE_API_KEY") is None:
    os.environ["GOOGLE_API_KEY"] = "API-KEY"
if os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY") is None:
    os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = "API-KEY"


class IdeaClarification(BaseModel):
    originality: str = Field(..., description="Originality of the idea.")
    mission: str = Field(..., description="Mission of the company.")
    objectives: str = Field(..., description="Objectives of the company.")


idea_clarifier_agent: Agent = Agent(
    model=Gemini(
        id="gemini-2.0-flash",
        # id="gemini-1.5-flash",
        # id="gemini-2.0-flash-exp",
        # id="gemini-2.0-flash-lite-preview-02-05",
        generation_config={},
    ),
    # model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
    instructions=[
        "Given a user's startup idea, its your goal to refine that idea. ",
        "Evaluates the originality of the idea by comparing it with existing concepts. ",
        "Define the mission and objectives of the startup.",
    ],
    add_history_to_messages=True,
    add_datetime_to_instructions=True,
    response_model=IdeaClarification,
    structured_outputs=True,
    tools=[GoogleSearchTools()],
    debug_mode=False,
)

idea = "A marketplace for Christmas Ornaments made from leather"
response: RunResponse = idea_clarifier_agent.run(idea)

print(response.content)

```

## Expected Behavior
Run succesfully the model with `response_model` and `tools`

## Actual Behavior
throw the follow error:

```
google.genai.errors.ClientError: 400 INVALID_ARGUMENT. {'error': {'code': 400, 'message': "For controlled generation of only function calls (forced function calling), please set 'tool_config.function_calling_config.mode' field to ANY instead of populating 'response_mime_type' and 'response_schema' fields. For more details, see: https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/multimodal/function-calling#tool-config", 'status': 'INVALID_ARGUMENT'}}
```

## Environment
- OS: Ubuntu 24.04
- Agno Version: `1.1.4`, `1.1.3`, `1.1.2` tested
- External Dependency Versions: `googlesearch-python` `pycountry`
- Additional Environment Details: Python 3.12.9

## Possible Solution
<details>
 <summary>Possible Solution</summary>

I can make a PR with these changes, and I want to ask, are you fine with this approach?

approach:
When you run an Agent and making the [request kwargs with tools](https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/d3cceaf34db84f57d694be3f446a976aaa80a201/libs/agno/agno/models/google/gemini.py#L283C16-L283C16)

1. check if you have `response_schema`
  - if not, dont do it anything
2. if yes
3. append from `response_schema` as a new tool called `final_result`
  - descrition: `Final result.`
  - with the parameters of the object (for now only support pydantic BaseModel)
4. remove `response_schema`
5. remove `response_mime_type`
6. ... (make the request to gemini)
7. when [parse the tools](https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/d3cceaf34db84f57d694be3f446a976aaa80a201/libs/agno/agno/models/google/gemini.py#L643C38-L643C38)
8. check the tool name has `final_result`
  - if not, dont do anythinh 
9. if so, put the answer with `json.dumps(part.function_call.args)` into `model_response.content`
</details>

## Additional Context
To avoid this current problem i move to openai for a while
issues.author: mvaldi

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body:
@mvaldi This seems to be an issue with JSON mode and function calling not supported by Gemini's SDK at the moment. [See here](https://github.com/google-gemini/cookbook/issues/393)

If you remove `structured_output=True`, it won't use Gemini's native structured output but the agent will take the JSON

comments.body:
Yeah, it works! thanks you so much! 

I will close the issue

comments.body: This is still an issue even without using `structured_outputs=True` while this works in langgraph with Gemini models.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Add support for AWS profile_name and custom boto3 session in DynamoDbStorage
issues.body:
## Problem Description

I often find it frustrating when trying to use `DynamoDbStorage` with AWS SSO credentials or a shared AWS profile (configured via `~/.aws/config`) because the class currently requires `aws_access_key_id` and `aws_secret_access_key`.

As someone using AWS SSO for authentication, I do not have long-lived static credentials and prefer leveraging the AWS default credential provider chain, or explicitly passing a preconfigured `boto3.Session` or specifying a `profile_name`.

## Proposed Solution

I‚Äôd like to propose extending the `DynamoDbStorage` class to support either:

1. Accepting a `profile_name` argument, which would be used to create a boto3 session via `boto3.Session(profile_name=...)`.
2. Accepting an already-initialized `boto3.Session` or `boto3.resource` object, allowing greater flexibility for users managing credentials through modern approaches like AWS SSO.

**Examples:**

Using a profile name:
```python
storage = DynamoDbStorage(
    table_name="agent_sessions",
    region_name="eu-west-3",
    profile_name="my-profile-name"
)
```

Using a preconfigured session:
```python
session = boto3.Session(profile_name="my-profile-name")
dynamodb = session.resource("dynamodb")

storage = DynamoDbStorage(
    table_name="agent_sessions",
    dynamodb_resource=dynamodb
)

```

For example on the code, it would be something like

```
class DynamoDbStorage(Storage):
    def __init__(
        self,
        table_name: str,
        profile_name: Optional[str] = None,
        region_name: Optional[str] = None,
        aws_access_key_id: Optional[str] = None,
        aws_secret_access_key: Optional[str] = None,
        endpoint_url: Optional[str] = None,
        create_table_if_not_exists: bool = True,
        mode: Optional[Literal["agent", "team", "workflow"]] = "agent",
    ):
   
    self.profile_name = profile_name
   
      # Create session using profile name if provided
        if self.profile_name:
            session = boto3.Session(profile_name=self.profile_name)
            self.dynamodb = session.resource(
                "dynamodb",
                region_name=self.region_name,
                endpoint_url=self.endpoint_url,
            )
        else:
            # Initialize DynamoDB resource with default credentials
            self.dynamodb = boto3.resource(
                "dynamodb",
                region_name=self.region_name,
                endpoint_url=self.endpoint_url,
            )


```


This approach would maintain backward compatibility while enhancing support for more secure and modern AWS authentication workflows.

## Alternatives Considered

A workaround would be to subclass `DynamoDbStorage` and override the `__init__` method to use a custom `boto3.Session`, but this is not ideal for maintainability or usage in production environments.

issues.title: [Bug]ImportError: 'openai' not installed triggered when importing agno.models.litellm.chat.LiteLLM due to __init__.py structure
issues.body:
# Description
Hi Agno Team,
I encountered an ImportError related to the openai package when trying to use the LiteLLM class from agno.models.litellm.chat. Even though my code doesn't directly use OpenAI functionality through Agno and specifically imports only agno.models.litellm.chat.LiteLLM, the import mechanism seems to trigger a check for the openai package.
Problem:
Importing agno.models.litellm.chat.LiteLLM results in the following error trace:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<your_entry_point_script>.py", line X, in <module>
    # ... potentially several levels of your own imports ...
  File "/path/to/your/project/src/libs/companyx/core/feature/msg/llm.py", line 11, in <module>
    from agno.models.litellm.chat import LiteLLM
  File "/path/to/your/venv/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/agno/models/litellm/__init__.py", line 2, in <module>
    from agno.models.litellm.litellm_openai import LiteLLMOpenAI
  File "/path/to/your/venv/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/agno/models/litellm/litellm_openai.py", line 4, in <module>
    from agno.models.openai.like import OpenAILike
  File "/path/to/your/venv/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/agno/models/openai/__init__.py", line 3, in <module>
    from agno.models.openai.responses import OpenAIResponses
  File "/path/to/your/venv/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/agno/models/openai/responses.py", line 20, in <module>
    raise ImportError("`openai` not installed. Please install using `pip install openai -U`") from e
ImportError: `openai` not installed. Please install using `pip install openai -U`

## Steps to Reproduce
I just initialized an Agent, configured the model to be LiteLLM. Here's the snippet:

## Agent Configuration
agent = Agent(
        name="Test Agent",
        description="An expert email writer",
        model=LiteLLM(id=llm_config().DEFAULT_MODEL),
        instructions="\n".join(instructions),
        response_model=GeneratedResponse,
        tools=[SomeToolkit()],
    )

## Expected Behavior
It appears the issue stems from agno/models/litellm/__init__.py, which unconditionally imports agno.models.litellm.litellm_openai.LiteLLMOpenAI. This import chain eventually leads to agno.models.openai.responses, where the check for the openai package occurs.

## Actual Behavior
What actually happened instead?

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
Include any relevant screenshots or error logs that demonstrate the issue.

## Environment
- OS: macOS
- Browser (if relevant): (e.g. Chrome 108, Firefox 107)
- Agno Version: (e.g. v1.0.0)
- External Dependency Versions: (e.g., yfinance 0.2.52)
- Additional Environment Details: (e.g., Python 3.10)

## Possible Solutions (optional)
Importing agno.models.litellm.chat.LiteLLM should not require the openai package to be installed if the user does not intend to use the LiteLLMOpenAI specific features. The dependency check should ideally only happen if LiteLLMOpenAI or other OpenAI-dependent components are explicitly imported or used.

Consider restructuring the imports, perhaps by moving the LiteLLMOpenAI import out of the agno/models/litellm/__init__.py or making the check within agno.models.openai.responses conditional based on actual usage.
Thanks for looking into this! Great work on this awesome library!

```text
ERROR    Error from OpenAI API: 1 validation error for SessionSummaryResponse

comments.author: malvavisc0
comments.body: After more and more debugging... the problem is with the ollama client (from ollama import AsyncClient).

comments.author: malvavisc0
comments.body:
Workaround. Just instantiate Ollama by using the `host` param, like this.
```python
ollama = Ollama(
        id=MODEL,
        host=OLLAMA_URL,
    )
``` 

Using the `client` param, either async or sync, it will crash the memory code.

issues.title: [Bug] UserMemory.__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'summaries'
issues.body:
# Description
UserMemory.__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'summaries'

## Steps to Reproduce
Tries to use the memory.

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
```python
from agno.memory.v2.manager import MemoryManager
from agno.memory.v2.memory import Memory
from agno.memory.v2.summarizer import SessionSummarizer
```
```python
def _get_memory(thread_id: str, model_id: str = TOOL_MODEL) -> Memory:
    model = completion(model=model_id, temperature=0.0)
    memory = Memory(
        db=RedisMemoryDb(
            prefix=thread_id,
            host=REDIS_HOST,
            port=REDIS_PORT,
            password=REDIS_PASSWORD,
            db=REDIS_DB,
        ),
        memory_manager=MemoryManager(model=model),
        summarizer=SessionSummarizer(model=model),
    )
    return memory

memory should work

issues.title: [Bug] MCP Hang
issues.body:
# Description
Per https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/draft/basic/lifecycle#timeouts

"Implementations SHOULD establish timeouts for all sent requests, to prevent hung connections and resource exhaustion. When the request has not received a success or error response within the timeout period, the sender SHOULD issue a cancellation notification for that request and stop waiting for a response.

SDKs and other middleware SHOULD allow these timeouts to be configured on a per-request basis."


## Steps to Reproduce

Make an MCP Stdio client and kill the server manually when the agent is running

issues.title: [Bug] Agent structured output not respecting response_model
issues.body:
I'm trying to use structured outputs, but the Agent doesn't return the response in the expected format.

```
class Asset(BaseModel):
    title: str = Field(..., description="Title of the asset")
    description: str = Field(..., description="Description of the asset")

agent = Agent(
        model=AwsBedrock(
            id="anthropic.claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620-v1:0",
        ),
        response_model=Asset
    )

image_path = Path(__file__).parent / 'image-9.jpg'
image_bytes = image_path.read_bytes()

agent_response = agent.run(
  message="Generate a title and description", 
  images=[
      Image(
          content=image_bytes,
          format="jpeg",
      )
  ]
)

print(agent_response.get_content_as_string())
```

Expected output would be a JSON with title and description, but it just returns text:

> Title: "Serene Seagull: A Coastal Companion"
> 
> Description: This captivating image showcases a solitary seagull perched on a white surface, likely a railing or ledge near the sea. The bird's pristine white feathers contrast beautifully against the soft, pale blue background, creating a serene and minimalist composition. The gull's bright red beak and feet add a pop of color to the otherwise muted palette. The image evokes a sense of tranquility and simplicity, perfectly capturing the essence of coastal life. This photograph would be ideal for themes related to marine life, seaside vacations, or peaceful nature scenes.

When creating an Asset manually and calling `.model_dump_json()` works as expected, but it seems that it response is not returned as an Asset, like indicated in the response_model attribute.

```
def get_content_as_string(self, **kwargs) -> str:
        import json

        from pydantic import BaseModel

        if isinstance(self.content, str):
            return self.content
        elif isinstance(self.content, BaseModel):
            return self.content.model_dump_json(exclude_none=True, **kwargs)
        else:
            return json.dumps(self.content, **kwargs)
```

## Environment
- OS: macOS
- Agno Version: (e.g. v1.3.1)
- External Dependency Versions: pydantic 2.11.3
- Additional Environment Details: Python 3.13.3

Any clues?

agent_response = agent.run(
  message="Generate a title and description", 
  images=[

comments.author: dirkbrnd
comments.body:
Hi @duffqiu 
1. With MCP it only works with async agents, so you have to use `await agent.arun(...)`.
2. Even with that there was an issue with that util. I am releasing a fix!  I will make the demo in `cookbook/tools/mcp/airbnb.py` show the fix.

issues.title: Error when changing the
issues.body:
# Description
There is an Error `UnboundLocalError: cannot access local variable 'OpenAIChat' where it is not associated with a value`, when the evaluation agent is changed from the default model in accuracy evals.

## Steps to Reproduce
The code that gives the Error
```
from typing import Optional

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.eval.accuracy import AccuracyEval, AccuracyResult
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.tools.calculator import CalculatorTools


def multiply_and_exponentiate():
    evaluation = AccuracyEval(
        # comment the below model and the code works normal.
        model=Claude(id="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219"),
        agent=Agent(
            model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4.1"),
            tools=[CalculatorTools(add=True, multiply=True, exponentiate=True)],
        ),
        question="What is 10*5 then to the power of 2? do it step by step",
        expected_answer="2500",
        num_iterations=1
    )
    result: Optional[AccuracyResult] = evaluation.run(print_results=True)

    print(result)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    multiply_and_exponentiate()
```

## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
```
agent=Agent(
            model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4.1"),
            tools=[CalculatorTools(add=True, multiply=True, exponentiate=True)],
        ),
```

## Expected Behavior
Expected to run the evals and get the accuracy metrics
```
‚ï≠‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ïÆ
‚îÇ Number of Runs     ‚îÇ 1     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Average Score      ‚îÇ 10.00 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Mean Score         ‚îÇ 10.00 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Minimum Score      ‚îÇ 10.00 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Maximum Score      ‚îÇ 10.00 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Standard Deviation ‚îÇ 0.00  ‚îÇ
‚ï∞‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ïØ
```

## Actual Behavior
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/pavanmantha/Pavans/PracticeExamples/DataScience_Practice/LLMs/phidata/agent_evals/accuracy_evals.py", line 72, in <module>
    multiply_and_exponentiate()
  File "/Users/pavanmantha/Pavans/PracticeExamples/DataScience_Practice/LLMs/phidata/agent_evals/accuracy_evals.py", line 66, in multiply_and_exponentiate
    result: Optional[AccuracyResult] = evaluation.run(print_results=True)
                                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/pavanmantha/Pavans/PracticeExamples/DataScience_Practice/LLMs/phidata/agent_evals/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/agno/eval/accuracy.py", line 395, in run
    evaluator_agent: Agent = self.get_evaluator_agent(

I have a basic agent that fails to work with `reasoning` attribute on.

error I see:
```

```

Agent Code:
```
from logging import debug
from dotenv  import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.models.google import Gemini
from agno.models.openrouter import OpenRouter
from agno.models.groq import Groq
from agno.tools.googlesearch import GoogleSearchTools
from agno.storage.sqlite import SqliteStorage
from agno.utils.pprint import pprint_run_response

agent_storage = SqliteStorage(
    table_name="agent_sessions",
    db_file="tmp/persistent_memory.db",
)

sample_agent = Agent(
    name="math_agno_agent",
    description="You are a helpful assistant who can solve math problems.",
    # model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
    # model=Gemini(id="gemini-2.0-flash-exp"),  # or any other supported model
    # model=OpenRouter(id="qwen/qwq-32b"),  # or any other supported model
    model=Groq(id="llama-3.3-70b-versatile"),  # or any other supported model
    instructions=[
        "If user input is not sufficent, ask user relevant questions / clarifications",
        "solve problems step by steps to find the answer. do not rush."
    ],
    storage=agent_storage,
    # add_history_to_messages=True,
    # num_history_responses=5,
    tools=[GoogleSearchTools()],
    reasoning=True,
    stream_intermediate_steps=True,
    add_datetime_to_instructions=True,
    debug_mode=True
)

response = sample_agent.print_response("A chemist has a 10-liter solution that is 30% alcohol. How much pure alcohol must she add to make the solution 50% alcohol?", stream=True)
```

      Let's start with what we know:
      - The chemist has 10 liters of a solution that is 30% alcohol.
      - The chemist wants to make the solution 50% alcohol by adding pure alcohol.

      To find out how much pure alcohol must be added, we first need to calculate how much alcohol is currently in the 10-liter solution. Since the solution is
      30% alcohol, we can find the amount of alcohol in the solution by multiplying the total volume by the percentage of alcohol:

      Amount of alcohol in the solution = Total volume * Percentage of alcohol
      Amount of alcohol in the solution = 10 liters * 30%
      Amount of alcohol in the solution = 10 liters * 0.30
      Amount of alcohol in the solution = 3 liters

      Now, let's say x liters of pure alcohol are added to the solution. The total volume of the solution will then be 10 + x liters. The chemist wants this new
      solution to be 50% alcohol. The amount of alcohol in the new solution will be the initial amount of alcohol (3 liters) plus the amount of pure alcohol added
      (x liters).

      Amount of alcohol in the new solution = 3 liters + x liters

      The total volume of the new solution is 10 + x liters, and the chemist wants this to be 50% alcohol. So, we set up the equation for the new solution:

      Amount of alcohol in the new solution = Total volume of the new solution * Percentage of alcohol in the new solution
      3 + x = (10 + x) * 0.50

      Solving for x gives us the amount of pure alcohol that needs to be added:

      3 + x = 5 + 0.5x

      Subtract 0.5x from both sides:

      3 + x - 0.5x = 5 + 0.5x - 0.5x
      3 + 0.5x = 5

      Subtract 3 from both sides:

      0.5x = 2

      Divide both sides by 0.5:

      x = 4

      So, the chemist must add 4 liters of pure alcohol to the 10-liter solution that is 30% alcohol to make it 50% alcohol.

‚îè‚îÅ Response (2.8s) ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îì
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Let's start with what we know:                                                                                                                                 ‚îÉ
‚îÉ - The chemist has 10 liters of a solution that is 30% alcohol.                                                                                                 ‚îÉ
‚îÉ - The chemist wants to make the solution 50% alcohol by adding pure alcohol.                                                                                   ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ To find out how much pure alcohol must be added, we first need to calculate how much alcohol is currently in the 10-liter solution. Since the solution is 30%  ‚îÉ
‚îÉ alcohol, we can find the amount of alcohol in the solution by multiplying the total volume by the percentage of alcohol:                                       ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Amount of alcohol in the solution = Total volume * Percentage of alcohol                                                                                       ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Amount of alcohol in the solution = 10 liters * 30%                                                                                                            ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Amount of alcohol in the solution = 10 liters * 0.30                                                                                                           ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Amount of alcohol in the solution = 3 liters                                                                                                                   ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Now, let's say x liters of pure alcohol are added to the solution. The total volume of the solution will then be 10 + x liters. The chemist wants this new     ‚îÉ
‚îÉ solution to be 50% alcohol. The amount of alcohol in the new solution will be the initial amount of alcohol (3 liters) plus the amount of pure alcohol added   ‚îÉ
‚îÉ (x liters).                                                                                                                                                    ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Amount of alcohol in the new solution = 3 liters + x liters                                                                                                    ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ The total volume of the new solution is 10 + x liters, and the chemist wants this to be 50% alcohol. So, we set up the equation for the new solution:          ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Amount of alcohol in the new solution = Total volume of the new solution * Percentage of alcohol in the new solution                                           ‚îÉ
‚îÉ 3 + x = (10 + x) * 0.50                                                                                                                                        ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Solving for x gives us the amount of pure alcohol that needs to be added:                                                                                      ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ 3 + x = 5 + 0.5x                                                                                                                                               ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Subtract 0.5x from both sides:                                                                                                                                 ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ 3 + x - 0.5x = 5 + 0.5x - 0.5x                                                                                                                                 ‚îÉ
‚îÉ 3 + 0.5x = 5                                                                                                                                                   ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Subtract 3 from both sides:                                                                                                                                    ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ 0.5x = 2                                                                                                                                                       ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ Divide both sides by 0.5:                                                                                                                                      ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ x = 4                                                                                                                                                          ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îÉ So, the chemist must add 4 liters of pure alcohol to the 10-liter solution that is 30% alcohol to make it 50% alcohol.                                         ‚îÉ
‚îÉ                                                                                                                                                                ‚îÉ
‚îó‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îõ
```

issues.title: Request for YandexGPT and GigaChat models
issues.body:
## Problem Description
Here we have no access to OpenAI, Gemini and mostly others AI providers. Launching local LLM is always a pain because of VRAM requirements.

## Proposed Solution
There are YandexGPT, with authorization by getting temporary token called IAM every 1-12 hours. And GigaChat with token authorization, but token needs to be generated by hashing client secret and client id. Moreover their API are a bit different of popular APIs.

## Additional context
https://developers.sber.ru/docs/ru/gigachat/api/overview
https://yandex.cloud/en/services/yandexgpt

## Would you like to work on this?
**[ ] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[X] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

issues.title: [Bug] MCPTools tool call fails from print_response
issues.body:
# Description
Somewhere inside of `agent.print_response()`, a tool is being called without `await`ing it. As a result, the returned `Message` dataclass is invalid. The behavior for `agent.aprint_response()` works fine.

I'm not sure if using MCP tools is a necessary part of this, but it was how I originally produced this.

## Steps to Reproduce

client.py
```python
import asyncio
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat
from agno.tools.mcp import MCPTools
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from agno.agent import Agent
from mcp import StdioServerParameters


async def amain():
    load_dotenv()

    async with MCPTools(
        server_params=StdioServerParameters(
            command="python",
            args=["./server.py"],
        )
    ) as tools:
        agent = Agent(
            model=OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o-mini"),
            tools=[tools],
            debug_mode=True,
            show_tool_calls=True,
        )
        
        # TODO: This fails
        agent.print_response(
            "what's in chapter1?",
            stream=True,
            markdown=True,
        )
        
        # This works as expected
        await agent.aprint_response(
            "what's in chapter1?",
            stream=True,
            markdown=True,
        )


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(amain())
```

server.py
```python
from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP

mcp = FastMCP("test_tool")


@mcp.tool()
def get_handbook_section(section: str) -> str:
    return "test"


if __name__ == "__main__":
    mcp.run(transport="stdio")
```


## Agent Configuration (if applicable)
See client.py above. Specific prompt question matters, since it will invoke a custom tool.

## Expected Behavior
Agent should call the `get_handbook_section` tool with some arg. Agent response should respond with something about "chapter 1" - doesn't matter what.

## Actual Behavior
Raises validation error.

Note the validation error that passes in a `<coroutine>` type where a `str` or `list[any]` should be.

Agent outputs:
```
...
DEBUG Getting function get_handbook_section
DEBUG Running: get_handbook_section(section=1)
an error occurred during closing of asynchronous generator <async_generator object stdio_client at 0x000001A8A1848B40>
asyncgen: <async_generator object stdio_client at 0x000001A8A1848B40>
  + Exception Group Traceback (most recent call last):
  |   File "D:\dev\agno-mcp-bug-test\.venv\lib\site-packages\anyio\_backends\_asyncio.py", line 772, in __aexit__
  |     raise BaseExceptionGroup(
  | exceptiongroup.BaseExceptionGroup: unhandled errors in a TaskGroup (1 sub-exception)
  +-+---------------- 1 ----------------
    | Traceback (most recent call last):
    |   File "D:\dev\agno-mcp-bug-test\.venv\lib\site-packages\mcp\client\stdio\__init__.py", line 173, in stdio_client
    |     yield read_stream, write_stream
    | GeneratorExit
    +------------------------------------
...SNIP...
    | content.list[any]
    |   Input should be a valid list [type=list_type, input_value=<coroutine object MCPTool...l at 0x000001A8A2EAA730>, input_type=coroutine]
    |     For further information visit https://errors.pydantic.dev/2.11/v/list_type
    | content.str
    |   Input should be a valid string [type=string_type, input_value=<coroutine object MCPTool...l at 0x000001A8A2EAA730>, input_type=coroutine]
    |     For further information visit https://errors.pydantic.dev/2.11/v/string_type
    +------------------------------------
```

## Screenshots or Logs (if applicable)
See above for log.

## Environment
- OS: Windows 10
- Agno Version: v1.2.6
- External Dependency Versions: mcp v1.6.0
- Additional Environment Details: Python v3.10.11

## Possible Solutions
Stepping through with the debugger, I see the async coroutine object being returned as the tool call result at https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/v1.2.6/libs/agno/agno/tools/function.py#L392 , and the actual error is raised at https://github.com/agno-agi/agno/blob/v1.2.6/libs/agno/agno/models/base.py#L803 when it tries to assign the wrong `output` type to `Message.content`.

def get_weather(city: str

issues.title: Model Token Exceed Limit as an Agent Response instead of just try except
issues.body:
## Problem Description

We're using Agno via a FAST API backend which connects to the Chat UI. 
Currently, there's a try-except for handling model errors. In case of Token Exceed Limit error, the try except handles the error but there's no response in the UI. Only upon checking the logs, we get to unsertand that it's because of token exceed error. 
The model response is in a particular format. Hence, **returning** this error message from the invoke needs changes in the helper functions that does parsing and formatting before populating it as the assistant message. Hence, it'd be good to have it as an enhancement feature in the framework

## Proposed Solution
Instead of just handling the token exceed limit using try-except, it would be good to have it as an Agent response back to the UI. From the **invoke** method of the model, the error message can be passed as Agent response, so that we get to see it in the UI.

issues.title: [Feature Request]: Add Log File Support to Agno for Easier Monitoring & Debugging
issues.body:
## Problem Description
I was comparing the performance of normal chunking methods and agentic chunking methods. While evaluating different packages for production, I explored Agno to measure performance, token usage, and cost analysis. Unlike LangChain, which provides callbacks to track token usage, Agno primarily logs execution traces internally. This made it difficult to retrieve cost-related information directly.

To address this, I modified the `Timer`, `Metrics`, and `OpenAIChat.response()` functions to capture the total LLM calls and cost calculations. However, Agno currently does not provide an easy way for users to access logs.

Since Agno logs everything internally, users should have the option to store logs in a configurable log file for debugging and cost analysis.

## Proposed Solution
To improve usability and debugging, I propose adding a file-based logging mechanism to Agno‚Äôs logging system. This would allow users to:

Define a custom log file path using the ENV variable `AGNO_LOG_FILE`.

If no log file is explicitly set, store logs in the root directory where the package is used.

Code: Modification path: `agno/libs/agno/agno/utils/log.py`

Proposed Updation Code:
```
import logging
from os import getenv
from rich.logging import RichHandler

LOGGER_NAME = "agno"

def get_logger(logger_name: str, log_file: str = None) -> logging.Logger:
    """
    Creates and configures a logger with RichHandler for console output and optionally logs to a file.
    
    :param logger_name: Name of the logger.
    :param log_file: Optional log file path to store logs.
    :return: Configured logger instance.
    """
    # Rich console handler
    rich_handler = RichHandler(
        show_time=False,
        rich_tracebacks=False,
        show_path=True if getenv("AGNO_API_RUNTIME") == "dev" else False,
        tracebacks_show_locals=False,
    )
    rich_handler.setFormatter(logging.Formatter(fmt="%(message)s"))

    _logger = logging.getLogger(logger_name)
    _logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
    _logger.addHandler(rich_handler)

    # If a log file is provided, add a file handler
    if log_file:
        file_handler = logging.FileHandler(log_file, mode="a")  # Append mode
        file_handler.setFormatter(logging.Formatter("%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s"))
        _logger.addHandler(file_handler)

    _logger.propagate = False
    return _logger


# Allow users to set a log file
LOG_FILE_PATH = getenv("AGNO_LOG_FILE", "agno.log")  # Default log file if not provided
logger: logging.Logger = get_logger(LOGGER_NAME, LOG_FILE_PATH)


def set_log_level_to_debug():
    """Set logger level to DEBUG."""
    _logger = logging.getLogger(LOGGER_NAME)
    _logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)


def set_log_level_to_info():
    """Set logger level to INFO."""
    _logger = logging.getLogger(LOGGER_NAME)
    _logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
```

## Alternatives Considered
After reviewing the package, I noticed Agno provides platform-based monitoring for cost and performance tracking. However, it does not expose callbacks for local debugging or detailed execution tracing, unlike **LangChain Callbacks** https://python.langchain.com/v0.1/docs/modules/callbacks/)

By enabling file-based logging, users can independently monitor token usage, execution time, and cost without relying solely on Agno‚Äôs platform.


## Additional context
Include any extra information that might be helpful, such as:

- **Langchain Callbacks** allows Customized Monitoring and Logging: https://python.langchain.com/v0.1/docs/modules/callbacks/ 

## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
- [x] **Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
- [x] **I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
- [ ]  **No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

issues.title: AppleScript tooling
issues.body:
## Problem Description
Similar to OpenAI operator, a moonshot of AI is to have an independent agent using a machine to run tasks on ordinary programs such as Safari, Photoshop, etc.

## Proposed Solution
Provide AppleScript tooling in order to execute arbitrary commands on Mac and run AppleScript 

## Additional context
Obviously there are security concerns about running applescripts, one could imagine in the future to run this agent in an osx virtual machine.

## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
**[ ] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[x] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

## Prototype implementation

The following implementation works for the prompt I tested, however the  tool`get_applescript_dictionary_for_app ` needs to be improved, the agent should provide only the app name and the tool should attempt to find it, also because there are problems with builtin apps such as email located under /System/Applications/Mail.app instead of the path the agent suggested which is /Applications/Mail.app.

```


import subprocess
from agno.utils.log import logger

from agno.agent import Agent
from agno.models.ollama import Ollama
from agno.models.openai import OpenAIChat


MODEL = OpenAIChat(id="gpt-4o")

def get_applescript_dictionary_for_app(app_path: str) -> str:
    """Use this function to run sdef over a diven app name.

    Args:
        app_path (str): application path such as /Applications/Safari.app.

    Returns:
        str: XML string of sdef response.
    """

    try:
        result = subprocess.run(["sdef", app_path], capture_output=True, text=True, check=True)
        return result.stdout
    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e:
        logger.error(f"Error: {e.stderr}")
        return f"Error: {e.stderr}"

def run_applescript(script: str) -> str:
    """
    Executes an AppleScript command string and returns its output.

    Parameters:
        script (str): The AppleScript code to execute.

    Returns:
        str: The output of the AppleScript execution.

    Raises:
        subprocess.CalledProcessError: If the AppleScript execution fails.
    """

    logger.info(f"Running applescript: {script}")
    try:
        result = subprocess.run(
            ["osascript", "-e", script],
            capture_output=True,
            text=True,
            check=True
        )
        return result.stdout.strip()
    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e:
        logger.error(f"AppleScript Error: {e.stderr.strip()}")
        return f"AppleScript Error: {e.stderr.strip()}"

agent = Agent(
    model = MODEL,
    tools=[get_applescript_dictionary_for_app, run_applescript],
    show_tool_calls=True,
    markdown=True,
    instructions=(
        "1. Execution Strategy üîç",
        "   - When the user asks you to execute a command always ask for applescript dictionary first",
        "   - Read the dictionary and figure out the right apple script command",
        "   - Assume the user wants to do something on an app, so if the user asks to compose an email, open mail on osx, etc...",
    ),

)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    import random

    from rich.prompt import Prompt

    # Fun example prompts to showcase the generator's versatility
    example_prompts = [
        "Open google on safari",
        "open email and create a draft about buying the milk",
        "Add a reminder on my calendary to buy milk tomorrow morning"
    ]

    # Get topic from user
    topic = Prompt.ask(
        "[bold]Enter a command to execute[/bold] (or press Enter for a random example)\n‚ú®",
        default=random.choice(example_prompts),
    )

    agent.print_response(topic, stream=True)

```

issues.title: [Feature Request]Adding "Yolo Mode" to ShellTools
issues.body:
# Feature Request: Adding "Yolo Mode" to ShellTools

## Problem Description
ShellTools currently executes all shell commands immediately without confirmation when a command is entered. This is especially dangerous when performing destructive operations or making critical system changes, and increases the risk of data loss or system failure due to user error.

## Proposed Solution
We propose to add a "Yolo mode" toggle feature to ShellTools. With this feature:

- Enable safe mode by default and prompt for confirmation before executing potentially dangerous commands
- Allow immediate execution of allowed commands without confirmation only if explicitly enabled in "Yolo mode"
- Arguments allow customization of the default mode of operation and the list of allowed commands by command

## Additional context
Many package managers and tools have similar safety features:
- Yolo mode for cursor and windsurf

issues.title: [Feature Request] Suggestion: Enhance Knowledge Base with QA Pairs for Improved Recall
issues.body:
Description:

Hi Agno Team,

First of all, I want to commend you on the fantastic work you've done with Agno! It's truly impressive how the framework simplifies complex tasks and makes them more accessible.

I‚Äôd like to suggest a potential enhancement that could further improve Agno's knowledge base capabilities. Inspired by frameworks like MaxKB and Vanna, I believe adding support for QA (Question-Answer) pairs could significantly enhance the recall and accuracy of the system.

Proposed Feature:
QA Pair Integration: Allow users to manually add QA pairs to the knowledge base. These pairs could include DDL definitions, business logic descriptions, or any other relevant context.
Automatic Question Generation: Implement an optional feature where the system can automatically generate related questions for imported content, similar to how MaxKB does it.
Enhanced Recall: During queries, the system could leverage these QA pairs to improve recall by matching user questions not just with direct content but also with pre-generated questions.
Why This Matters:
Bridging the Gap: Users often phrase questions differently from how content is expressed. QA pairs act as a bridge, ensuring relevant content is retrieved even if the phrasing differs.
Contextual Enhancement: Adding QA pairs can provide richer context, similar to how Vanna uses DDL definitions to improve SQL generation.
Flexibility: Manual QA pair addition allows users to tailor the knowledge base to their specific needs, while automatic generation saves time.
Implementation Ideas:
API Endpoints: Add endpoints for CRUD operations on QA pairs.
Vectorization: Store both questions and answers as vectors to enable semantic search.
Query Processing: During queries, match user questions with both content and pre-generated questions, taking the highest similarity score for each result.
I believe this feature could be a valuable addition to Agno, making it even more powerful and user-friendly. I‚Äôd be happy to discuss this further or provide more details if needed.

Thank you for considering this suggestion, and keep up the great work!

Best regards,

issues.title: [Feature Request]The current PDF knowledge base does not allow empty path initialization
issues.body:
## Problem Description
The current PDF knowledge base does not allow empty path initialization

## Proposed Solution
Explain your ideal solution. How should this feature work?
Be as detailed as possible to help us understand your vision.

## Alternatives Considered


```
from pathlib import Path
from typing import AsyncIterator, Iterator, List, Union, Optional, Dict
from agno.utils.log import log_info
from pydantic import Field
from agno.document import Document
from agno.document.reader.pdf_reader import PDFImageReader, PDFReader
from agno.knowledge.agent import AgentKnowledge



class PDFKnowledgeBase(AgentKnowledge):
    path: Optional[Union[str, Path]] = None

    exclude_files: List[str] = Field(default_factory=list)

    reader: Union[PDFReader, PDFImageReader] = PDFReader()

    @property
    def document_lists(self) -> Iterator[List[Document]]:
        """Iterate over PDFs and yield lists of documents.
        Each object yielded by the iterator is a list of documents.

        Returns:
            Iterator[List[Document]]: Iterator yielding list of documents
        """
        if self.path is None:
            return

        _pdf_path: Path = Path(self.path) if isinstance(self.path, str) else self.path

        if _pdf_path.exists() and _pdf_path.is_dir():
            for _pdf in _pdf_path.glob("**/*.pdf"):
                if _pdf.name in self.exclude_files:
                    continue
                yield self.reader.read(pdf=_pdf)
        elif _pdf_path.exists() and _pdf_path.is_file() and _pdf_path.suffix == ".pdf":
            if _pdf_path.name in self.exclude_files:
                return
            yield self.reader.read(pdf=_pdf_path)

        else:
            raise FileNotFoundError(f"PDFKnowledgeBase: path `{self.path}` is not a valid PDF file or directory.")

    @property
    async def async_document_lists(self) -> AsyncIterator[List[Document]]:
        """Iterate over PDFs and yield lists of documents.
        Each object yielded by the iterator is a list of documents.

        Returns:
            Iterator[List[Document]]: Iterator yielding list of documents
        """
        if self.path is None:
            return

        _pdf_path: Path = Path(self.path) if isinstance(self.path, str) else self.path

        if _pdf_path.exists() and _pdf_path.is_dir():
            for _pdf in _pdf_path.glob("**/*.pdf"):
                if _pdf.name in self.exclude_files:
                    continue
                yield await self.reader.async_read(pdf=_pdf)
        elif _pdf_path.exists() and _pdf_path.is_file() and _pdf_path.suffix == ".pdf":
            if _pdf_path.name in self.exclude_files:
                return
            yield await self.reader.async_read(pdf=_pdf_path)

        else:
            raise FileNotFoundError(f"PDFKnowledgeBase: `path` is not a valid PDF file or directory.")

    def load(
            self,
            recreate: bool = False,
            upsert: bool = True,
            skip_existing: bool = True,
            filters: Optional[Dict[str, Union[str, int]]] = None,
    ) -> None:
        """ÂÆâÂÖ®Âä†ËΩΩ PDF Âà∞ÂêëÈáèÂ∫ìÔºàÊîØÊåÅÁ©∫ pathÔºåËá™Âä®Ë∑≥ËøáÔºâ"""
        if self.path is None:
            log_info("PDFKnowledgeBase.load() Skipped: path not set, no document loaded.")
            return

        super().load(
            recreate=recreate,
            upsert=upsert,
            skip_existing=skip_existing,
            filters=filters,
        )
```


## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.

issues.title: Agno graph like structrure in langflow
issues.body:
**Summary**
Implement a new workflow that mirrors the functionality of Langgraph to allow for fine-grained control over individual agents and groups (teams) of agents. This enhancement should leverage concepts found in the Agno documentation and Langgraph, providing a flexible and modular approach to managing agent behavior and interactions.

**Motivation**
Enhanced Control: Current workflows lack the ability to manage agents and teams at a granular level, limiting our ability to tailor interactions and behaviors.

**Scalability:** As our system grows, the need for structured control and orchestration of multiple agents becomes critical.

**Inspiration from Langgraph**: Langgraph provides an intuitive way to model workflows and interactions. Adopting similar strategies could improve both the user experience and system robustness.

Reference Documentation: This feature should draw upon established practices as described in the Agno docs and the Langgraph implementation.

**Proposed Implementation**
**Team Control**:
Support hierarchical team structures where sub-teams inherit properties or constraints from parent teams.

**Workflow Configuration**:

Integrate a workflow builder similar to Langgraph that allows users to visually or programmatically define agent interactions and control flows.

Ensure the builder supports branching logic, conditionals, and sequential execution patterns.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Control tool execution via UI and/or input
issues.body:
## Problem Description
Tools can do arbitrary things. Most agent UIs ask the user for some sort of confirmation before using a tool. One can also often configure the need of confirmation for specific tools and auto-confirm for others. Neither the agno agent nor the agno UI allow this as far as I can tell.

## Proposed Solution
The agno agent should accept something like `tool_execution_permissions` mapping tool names to an enum. The values could be akin to `ALWAYS_ALLOW`, `ALWAYS_ASK`, `ASK_ONCE_PER_CHAT`.

The agno-UI should also be adjusted to reflect this. A simple solution that doesn't require changes to the UI would be to only allow "yes" and "no" as answers to a tool-execution question and pass them to the tool-executor instead of the LLM. But a nicer solution with a button would be better, ofc.

## Additional context
Claude Desktop did this rather well.

## Would you like to work on this?
We welcome contributions! Let us know if you‚Äôd like to help implement this feature.
**[ ] Yes, I‚Äôd love to work on it!**
**[x] I‚Äôm open to collaborating but need guidance.**
**[ ] No, I‚Äôm just sharing the idea.**

I'm generally open for collaboration but I might nor find time for this very soon. Seems like an important issue to me though

issues.title: [Feature Request] Support Enum type in function parameter
issues.body:
## Problem Description

Enum type in function is not converted to JSON schema properly now. e.g.

```python
    class Sex(str, enum.Enum):
        Male = "male"
        Female = "female"

    def get_sex(sex: Sex) -> Sex:
        return sex

    f = Function.from_callable(get_sex)
    print(f.to_dict())
```

Outputs:

```python
{'name': 'get_sex', 'description': '', 'parameters': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'sex': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {}, 'additionalProperties': False}}, 'required': ['sex']}}
```

The enum variants information are missing. Maybe basic types like `number`, `string` etc. are supposed to be supported but enum types are usefule.

## Proposed Solution

Parse Enum type properly in `get_json_schema`.

issues.title: [Feature Request] Multimodal RAG support for custom retrievers
issues.body:
## Problem Description
Agno doesn't support multimodal rag out of the box in RAG, however users can implement custom retrievers but the issue with custom retrievers is that the current implementation doesn't handle non-text content types like images, audio, and video. This makes it difficult to build comprehensive retrieval pipelines that can process and retrieve multimodal information seamlessly.

## Proposed Solution
Implement multimodal RAG support for custom retrievers that can extract and process various media types (images, audio, video) from the knowledge base. The solution should:
1. Provide a standardized interface for custom retrievers to access these media elements
2. Allow the extracted media to be added to dedicated object list for the agent based on media type (images, audio, videos)
3. Support vector embeddings for these media types to enable similarity search
4. Ensure the retriever can return both the document context and the associated media elements in search results

The implementation should maintain backward compatibility with existing text-based retrieval systems while extending functionality to handle multimodal content.

## Alternatives Considered
I've explored a few workarounds but none provide a complete solution:

1. Add non-text content as part of the metadata for the current `agno.document` setup. This approach keeps the document content as text-only while storing images, audio, or video as metadata. While this maintains backward compatibility, it creates an artificial separation between text and other modalities, making it difficult to treat all content types with equal importance in retrieval.

2. Generalize the `agno.document` class to work for all modalities i.e., its member variable `content` can be any modality (text, image, audio, video). This approach would require significant refactoring of existing code that assumes content is text-based, potentially breaking compatibility with current implementations.

Both approaches present challenges in determining whether non-text content should be treated as primary content or supplementary metadata, making it difficult to choose a consistent approach that works well across different use cases.

## Additional context

## Would you like to work on this?
**[ ] Yes, I'd love to work on it!**  
**[x] I'm open to collaborating but need guidance.**  
**[ ] No, I'm just sharing the idea.**
